posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is for the discussion of classic, or "retro" games, including consoles, computer games, arcade games (including pinball) and any other forms of video games. Retro gaming means platforms launched in 2001 and earlier, and official game titles for those platforms released no later than December 2007 (homebrew console games made after this date will be permitted). The Microsoft Xbox, Nintendo GameCube, Nintendo Game Boy Advance, and Sony PlayStation 2 will now be considered "retro".

Helpful links:
Game Tech Wiki
Emulation General Wiki

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9539441
I love my CRT, but even I admit that we're getting VERY close to the full obsolescence of CRTs. OLED motion clarity at 240hz is nearly identical, and input lag has come down to 4ms — that's far more appealing than the 1-16ms of variable input lag you'll get on a CRT. Unfortunately Windows has a baseline 32ms of input lag, so any sort of emulation is incapable of competing with a CRT. Video scalers with genuine hardware represents our last step towards the final goal.

I've noticed on console to HDMI adapters (xbox, ps2, wii) that the games don't always fill the entire screen. Often there are black bars on the sides, even in "widescreen" on the system setting. My suspicion is that the games always rendered this way, and the consoles/TVs just stretched the image to fit, where these adapters just tell the monitor/TV over HDMI not to fuck with anything, so you get the "native" rendering. I could be wrong though. It's kind of interesting, Xbox games show up as rendering at 720x480, which isn't 16:9 at all. Didn't know that 480 widescreen wasn't always 16:9, guess because the first time I had a widescreen TV was in the HDMI era.

Anyway, what's up with the games not filling the full screen anymore? Do these higher-quality boxes fix that, or allow you to manipulate the screen image to fit?

>Xbox games show up as rendering at 720x480, which isn't 16:9 at all

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
My recommendations for order play through and platform.

1. RE 96 or Directors cut (non-dual shock) PS1 on CRT
2. RE2 '98 PS1 or DC on CRT
3 RE3 '99 PS1 or DC on CRT
4. CODE VERONICA X (GCN or "PS2 Classic" version on PS4, stay away from the PS2 version and the HD MT Framework versions)
5. REmake PC or GCN + CRT
6. RE0 PC or GCN + CRT
7. Biohazard Outbreak Files 1+2 w/English patch on pscx2 with online via the outbreak resurrection server
8. RE4 PC + HD mod or GCN on CRT
9. RE5 GOLD PC
10. Revelations 1+2 PC
11. RE6 PC
12. RE7 GOLD PC
14. RE8 GOLD PC

Gits and shiggles if you really enjoy the series:
Umbrella Chronicles/Darkside Chronicles on Wii/Dolphin, Gun Survivor 2 w/ light gun or mouse

If you are a completionist:
RE Gaiden GBC and Gun Survivor JPN w/ lightgun

>>9544364

Honestly I'm more impressed by someone being a video game programmer back in the day, even if they were shit at it, because it was a new field and not at all prestigious or lucrative.
People were coding stuff in their spare time at home and mostly dealing with how to implement ideas they randomly had or trying to reverse-engineer games they liked. Nothing was done for fame or virtue signaling.

I remember my dad used to buy these ZX81/Spectrum magazines that had entire pages of code in them. You would literally transcribe the code from the magazine and you got a playable game out of it.
Point being that there was a love and pursuit of discovery there and the entire gaming field was uncharted waters. Real pioneers.

>>9541616
The original is Lotus Esprit Turbo Challenge on the Amiga. Lotus Turbo Challenge II is almost as good, but not a racing game. (Don't bother with the megadrive version).

The whole aesthetic and gameplay of the SNES Top Gear games is based on those, but to my mind takes a biiig step toward the casual. The original Amiga game is the greatest scaling racer ever made, though you may have to get your teeth into it to appreciate why. It's like discovering a completely new class of motorsport.

Not only aesthetics, they share the same engine IIRC.

To me it has the most precise, tight controls in the genre. >To me it has the most precise, tight controls in the genre. Most of the sprite scalers fuck up the speed of the player's sprite movement, but most importantly, turning animation frequently doesn't match the actual turn, which is very disorienting. That's an excellent way of putting it. There's a sense of momentum and timing that good racing games share, even if it's never the same sense of momentum and timing.

Interesting to hear about the engine. I'm sure it'd be a later iteration, or one taking advantage of the things the SNES does better, but the feel was always similar in a lot of regards. Just way worse on the SNES because they made it slippery and console-like - almost like Europlatforming, somehow - where the Amiga originals have a much smoother feeling and presentation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Almost one week with the RG351v (ARKos). Thoughts so far:

- Battery reading is pretty inaccurate. Sometimes you turn it off, turn it on and the next time the percentage is a 1% higher

- Battery + built in wifi = bad: If you are going to download thumbnails / boxart or update cores / assets, do it while connected to the DC and disable wifi immediately after. It sucked a 30% just doing that.

- Gaming experience: Surprised to see it can do CPS3 with not a lot of hiccups. GBA paired with the LCD3X shader mitigates well enough the scaling artifacts when not using integer scaling. 240p PSX games like Klonoa are the ones that benefit the most from the small screen. Snes and Nes are as annoying as ever with the non square pixels if you have bad OCPD about stretching artifacts, as usual.

- Comfort: The d-pad is placed higher than on the og gameboy, so the corner gets into the soft of the hand and hurts a bit until you learn to adapt the posture. The analog stick placement justifies why I did not want the model with two of them. For Ridge Racer Type 4 I just place the left hand lower to not feel it too much. If I really wanted to play an analog only game, I would end using the Gamesir X2 instead.

- Commuting and travelling: Beats lugging around a Nintendo Switch for a quickie in the train. Easier to store. Loses points for not having bluetooth. I can do without wifi, but headphone cables are always a risk

- Did I really need this: Sure, it's cool to be able to play MVS Meta Slug X on the go, but then I ask myself why would I want to play on a "tiny screen" when I can do it on a 40" tv and see all the details. It's great as a replacement for aging handheld consoles, but for TV out consoles it may be better to get one of the other handhelds with bigger screens

That's it for now, I guess. Decent hardware, Need to find a pouch for it. the grey color, rather than the old GB, reminds me more of the Watara Supervisision.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Force Engine Linux port with working Audio and MIDI playback thanks to mlauss!
https://github.com/mlauss/TheForceEngine/tree/test-audio-select

Clone branch and compile then start Fluidsynth with
> fluidsynth -a alsa -m alsa_seq -g 1.0 -s /usr/share/sounds/sf3/default-GM.sf3
(or similar)

Then run the compiled binary and go to Settings > Sound > MIDI Output Device and specify the MIDI Output Device.

Enjoy!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9540012
>>9540247
I think this map is okay but I have many nitpicks that I'll try to address roughly in order of appearance. I wish there were a few more bullets at the start since shooting the elevated skeletons at the start feels drawn out with the shotgun. I really dislike that some of the rock/sand piles around the start have impassible lines for no reason since it can block your dodging without any telegraph. This is especially annoying since not all of them are like this. Like the other post said already, many descended midtextures are visibly clipping through the floor with software rendering (you can fix this by varying the brightness value or flat between the surrounding sectors). The ambush before the rocket launcher is a blatant example of hitscanners without cover, the computer in the center isn't tall enough to protect you. I wish there were some consistency about which doors are intractable since inert/onesided doors look the same as normal ones. Using spectres as soon as you enter a dark room twice in the same map feels kind of lazy. Both archviles feel poorly used since the first one is trivial since he can never get behind you and the other is just a test of patience since it can never get down the lift. I didn't realize there was a lift at first since there's no indication it's intractable and it looks the same as the surrounding walls. I feel like the revenant/imp ambush by the computer switches would work a lot better if the wall above you were shorter so the enemies could shoot down at you when they get caught against the wall. I have no idea what the switch before the blue key lift is for since it seems like you can and should safely ignore it. The lost souls in the end room feel completely pointless since you can just kill them before you hit the switch, I'd honestly just remove them since the fight's hard enough anyway. You can also softlock yourself if you ride the perpetual lifts in that room up and jump over the wall. Cont.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541481
A lot of the interconnectedness in this level feels unmotivated since it'll often lead you places you have no reason to return to. The visuals in the map are unpolished, I don't know why you'd use a high quality texture pack like Otex if you aren't even going to align your textures (not just aligning your similar textures to each other but also aligning seams of the textures with the edges of geometry. Otex was designed from the ground up for this, I'm not sure why so many people don't bother). Using a combination of stock and Otex also tends to look incongruous, you can sometimes get away with it but it shouldn't really be necessary given the latter's comprehensiveness.
This probably comes off as a scathing review but I'd like to stress that none of these things ruin the map, and I liked many of the ideas present even if the execution was flawed. I especially liked the big imp ambush and the last room, minus the lost souls. If you're interested in contributing to community projects I'd say you're already more capable than a lot of participants.

>>9542926
The problem is that, A, this requires the attention of sufficiently educated and dedicated programmers who know Build, and then, B, for the ones who do to get over that Mapster32 really is an antiquated piece of shit which is holding the community back.

You know one of the big reasons Doom's mapping got such a powerful second wind in the 2000s? Because Doom Builder became a thing, and Doom Builder was a MONUMENTAL evolution in map making software for the game, all the programs proceeding it where clunky and awkward pieces of shit which sucked to use, with Doom Builder being incredibly easy to use and convenient, that program is one of the most important things in this community. Build modding and mapping communities clinging to Mapster32 is like if the Doom community had refused to move past DeepSEA, that shit would have murdered our momentum.

Build mapping is inherently more complex than mapping for Doom or any derivative of it, so the barrier of entry will remain higher, but the tools do not need to be this horrible relic.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9542820
I suggest trying to break out of the "room to door to room to door and repeat" layout cycle.
Also the texturing is very ugly. It looks like you're trying to fit in as many colors as possible, which ends up blurring the level's theme. A lot of these textures don't fit together. Moss-filled gray bricks with bright startans, solid grays, wood, bright tech blues, planks and bright silver... this all doesn't really fit together. It's best to stick to a few select textures that will be mainly used throughout the whole level or particular sections of it, if wanted, transitioning between themes smoothly.
The layout looks very basic and flat indeed, and I can tell there's not much reason behind those enemy placements: two Arachnotrons in a small, tight corridor. Arachnotrons fit best in large rooms, due to their big size and continuous attack that covers a lot of ground, much like Mancubi.
There's a lot of unintuitive cannon fodder fights, such as zombiemen with pinkies, or a block formation of Imps, and a few lone shotgunners that will provide absolutely no challenge or incentive interesting movement from the player. There's a single Baron that the player will either encounter after activating a lift down or that is defending the top of the staircase, again, in a tight corridor, with enough space that a single Baron is probably just gonna serve as a boring meatshield.
Last but not least... I'm betting you're using CC4-tex? Drop that shit. Ugly texture pack imo. Those recolors of vanilla textures (such as the ugly brown/orange space door) are so... unnecessary.

Might want to check out CRPG addicts blog. He is an expert in all things old CRPG and talks about his personal experiences.

From what I've read of history wizardry is part of generation 1 of computer RPGs. IE they only existed on pen and paper before so it was ground-breaking. There was a generation of zero for the PEDIT5, a super computer that only existed at some California university, and some important people on the wizardry team played PEDIT5 games. Before PEDIT5 it was all paper.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The initial release of Wizardry 1 was so turbo bullshit hard for all the wrong reasons they got so many complaints it got changed almost immediately.

The change made it impossible for the party that got an initial bonus round of actions due to a preemptive attack could not use magic during this round. In the original release magic could be used, which basically meant that if you got surprised by a group of spellcasters lategame, they could very very easily party wipe you with really strong spells before you even got to act. If Werdna surprised you you were almost certainly fucked.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9544682
To add to this.

Casual gamers did not exist back then. As in zero people on earth were casual gamers. If you owned a computer at all you were a nerd, high iq, and not afraid of difficult things (since computers were not user friendly). If you knew enough about RPGs to even understand what the hell is going in Wizardry or what the point is you were a nerd, high iq, and the only type of fantasy adventure you knew were one's with permadeath.

This was not something you bought at walmart. It was cutting edge stuff for the most hardcore of enthusiasts. The wizardry devs literally played the very fast CRPGs in existence at the one college on the planet that had the single computer that was powerful enough to run them. So of course their mind set and passion would seem totally alien to most people today.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I was a little kid in the late 80s when my mom bought me a complete and used copy of Wizardy 1 for Apple compatible computers. This was on our Apple Laser before it broke and then we got an Apple IIgs. The box and manuals are awesome and the artwork is hand drawn. It feels very personal.
The game itself is a fun computer adapted D&D game. It’s an rpg but different from something like the Ultima series.
It’s just fun to name a guy or girl after something random after you bang on the keyboard and whoever survives the longest gets to be a permanent character. Did this in the Bard’s Tale 1 as well. If “A” dies then fuk him but “D” survived and gained a few levels so he get’s a proper name or maybe we just left him named “D” like Vampire Hunter D (the anime).
It’s the gameplay, advancing levels, caring about your character, the artwork in the manual, and basic story that make you want to play it.
>I never beat it…

>>9533387
It does but it's a huge pain. The only way I can get DualShock rumble to work the way it does on console is to add Duckstation to Steam so it sees it as an Xinput controller, then change the vibration bias to like 138 in the controller options to actually get it to vibrate each motor correctly. Otherwise Playstation controllers overall don't rumble right when wrapped as Xinput (even the DS4 it turns out, although Duckstation supports that natively) and support for vibration as a Dinput controller is non-existent. I think you can accomplish this in PCSX2 as well (and I think that has some DS3 mode which might work for that controller, or is that RPCS3?) by changing the vibration percentages above 100% but I don't actually use PCSX2 so I'm not going to fiddle with it.

There's an Xbox One converter and I have no idea if it handles it any better and accounts for the different vibration standards or just does the same shit as the software input wrappers.

>>9542969
>The Dig has a great soundtrack
>but so do FF Mario and Zelda

Let's be honest, none of their soundtracks are actually legitimately emotional moving to any degree. If you go into any of those games blind, their soundtracks are serviceable, yes, even good at times, but the vast majority of their "music" wasn't made by actual musicians.

Koji Kondo, who developed music for Mario and Zelda, was neither classically trained or educated in music theory, musical instruments, or had any actual experience in either of those fields on a personal or professional level before becoming involved in video game development. A lot of the love around the music centers more on the games themselves being good rather than the pieces being genuinely works of art.

The difference is night and day when you compare literally anything Koji Kondo has ever written, to a single piece by someone who had an upbringing in the music field, like Martin O'Donnell.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=N22STVAxL5M
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0jXTBAGv9ZQ

The evidence is also there for The Dig, where the soundtrack is one of the most praised aspects of the game, and one of the reasons it is ranked so highly to begin with. This is because Michael Land also has an upbringing with music, taught piano early and educated in music at Harvard. Throughout the 90's, you would be hard-pressed to find a single mention of the soundtrack for many Japanese games. The Japanese just aren't that good at making music, their soundtracks are merely thought of as classic because they belong to the much better programming and design of the actual games.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This post is dedicated to a set of 4 digimon video games surrounding the events and story of Ryo Akiama

The series sort of existed as the Pokémon analog on the wonder swan series of consoles. Being RPGs centered around battling colorful monsters, and interacting with your friends irl

The first game Anode/Cathode Tamer, takes place soon after the original digimon adventure season. You play as Ryo (or whatever you decide to name him) on a journey to rescue the main characters from the revived baddies from that original season of the anime.

It’s a turn based tact type RPG on an isometric grid. It’s standout feature is the vast customizability of your 3 character team by teaching your mons “variables” which act as special attacks and abilities using evolved digimon forms


Ryo isn’t quite a normal digi-destined. He doesn’t have a digivice, or a partner digimon.
The lack of a partner means that the player has a large roster of characters to pick from. Including the main set from the anime.
Not having a digivice means that Ryo can’t quite take advantage of digivolution in the normal way.
Digivolution

Instead, evolution is used in the variable system.
Digimon put in a team together will teach each-other new variables, based on who you’ve paired up.

Using these in battle will call an attack from higher level digimon

It has a simple story and well paced gameplay. It’s also not particularly hard with just a little bit of strategy
The game is a few hours long, and is more or less dungeon to dungeon, very straight to the point
It can be pretty fun trying to figure out who plus who will give you what attacks, and try to build up a team of 3 bad asses.

Over all, it doesn’t have much wrong with it per say- but in the end its only alright. Worth taking a shot at in an emulator if you like this type of game. It will probably happily distract you for an afternoon or two.
Also, this game got an official color English remake. Look for the one labeled “veedramon version”

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9544912

The second game in the series is a complete mix up in terms of gameplay. The tactical RPG aspect is gone. Replaced with a more traditional 3v3 style or battles
The main aspects of variety and customization hold very true though. And connectivity with friends is just as much present

In this game, soon after the events of the first- Ryo is summoned back to the digital world to deal with more business.

(These games center around a big baddie: millenniumon. He’s not super important in the last game. Just the final boss. But he becomes more and more relevant as this mini series continues)

So millenniumon is causing trouble, and Ryo is summoned by a very familiar Veemon to help out. Ken ichihouji (yes the same one from 02, this game serves as his backstory) tags along

Shortly after arriving Ryo and Ken get trapped on alternate sides of the same universe. They can’t directly collaborate- but are both instrumental to foiling the villains and piecing the world back together.

The gameplay as stated is now a 3v3 turn based rpg. Digimon can learn a variety of attacks from one another, and can now digivolve into more powerful forms permanently.

A big part of this game is fusion.
By fusing two digimon together, you get a digi egg that can retain the learnt and native abilities of both the parents. And grow even stronger than before, and digivolve further than they previously could.

This game acts as a bit of a set up for season 2 of the anime. Explaining how Ken and wormmon meet, why Ken turns evil, and how the digi Eggs got scattered all over the digital world for the 02 kids to find.

This game OWNS
The gameplay loop of fusing digimon to get stronger digimon to catch more digimon to fuse with your fusions is so so so addictive. Quickly you’ll end up with digimon who’s family lineage goes back 30+ generations of fusions even MORE by the end of the game

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9544941
It’s so satasfing to see all of the best attributes from so many cool ass characters come together to make someone that’s entirely yours. I can only imagine how cool that would be in the context of you and your friends all playing the game together as kids.
I’ve only got my brother to battle and trade with and it still kicks ass


Thankfully the third and fourth game pick up and evolve the concepts from tag tamers.

D1 tamers is the epitome of “alright hot shit go nuts” the game has 0 qualms with you putting together a kickass team of 3 megas before the game even picks up.
This game added a LOT of digi eggs that can be added to fusions. These might add new attacks to the new mon, give them buffs or resistance to certain attacks. Your team is VERY customizable with 6 move slots each and the ability to alter modifiers through the digi egg fusing. It’s really cool.

This game even had online multiplayer and DLC back in the day. Doesn’t do much for us now but it’s indicative of the scope at play.

Story wise this one is the lightest. Ryo gets summoned back because evil is doing evil things go stop it. Ken sits this one out because he’s sick (in reality it’s the dark spores turning him evil and stuff but they don’t know that)

soon it’s revealed that 4 great spirits are hosting a tournament to see who the strongest tamer is. That winner which will be you if you play the game to the end, will go and stop millenniumon again because he’s being bad again.

This brings us to the tournaments. Which are a bit of a sore spot for me

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9544971
Tournaments happen at key checkpoint’s throughout the story. And you’ll typically end up fighting the main characters from the show.
You’ve gotta win 3 rounds back to back to complete a tournament. Sounds fine right?

Well the catch is that tournament battles are 100% automated.


And the Ai sucks ass


You need to have a team that’s both strong enough to win, but stronGER enough so that it can still win with the AIs MASSIVE handicap
Seriously your dudes will end up using ineffective attacks some turns.

Also means efficiency is kind of important when making your team. It’s a push to make sure that no attacks are useless. And that you really are making the best guys you can.
That cheap 1-2 combo cant carry you through the tournament if your digimon is too retarded to use it. So make sure it’s whole move set is good. Wouldn’t want your mega wasting turns on spitting out baby bubble.

obviously they did this on purpose. And it’s really not that bad. Just think a little bit when you put your teams together.

Also tournaments block the disabling of skipping battle animations which is BULLSHIT. have a speed up button handy for these. Trust me.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9544975
All in all D1 tamers is a very appreciated evolution of tag tamers. Adding new mons, new attacks, more mechanics for customization etc.

Brave tamer shakes things up a bit though.

Without spoiling the end of D1 tamer, I’ll just say Ryo is now in a new place without many memories to go off of.
This new place is actually the season 3 digimon tamers universe. Which fans will know is disconnected from the season 1 and 2 universe.

Ryo ends up here after traveling time and space. And will hop back and forth between dimensions throughout the game. Meeting up with tamers and recruiting digimon from all 3 seasons of the anime.

Digimon fusing is out. Well sorta. In the tamers universe, cards are the hot shit.
Cards are what will help customize your digimon on your 3 monster team. Cards can be fused, summoned, traded etc. it ends up where you can actually have MORE control over what your team ends up like. ESPECIALLY when you consider you can literally balance the stat tree of any of your party members whenever you want. Wanna spec all into speed? Sure need a balance of attack and defense? Go for it.

This game has a good bit of narrative to it. And sets up Ryo to go join the Tamers universe and end up being one of the main characters of season 3. Alongside his partner cyberdramon.

This game kicks ass.
Unfortunately it’s the only one which doesn’t have a currently complete English translation.
If you play with one of those auto translators though it works perfectly fine. The dialog in the game has no issues getting recognized.

(It’s also not very complex language, it’s written so little kids can understand so even just kinda knowing a bit of Japanese is plenty enough)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9544998
Fun thing about this series. All of these games can connect.
You can DIRECTLY transfer digimon from tag tamers to D1 to brave tamer

You can ALSO battle and even import digimon raised on a whole FUCK TON of various 90s and 2000s virtual pet keychains.

You can even even link up to the PlayStation to battle your moms in 3D with tag and D1 tamers

This mini series is rad. And I love them all to death. Tag, D1, and brave tamer especially. Anode/cathode is alright but the other 3 NAIL it

I hope at least one or two of you guys reads this and gives these games a shot.
They’re not very long, but they’re a lot of fun and have entertained me for hours.
They don’t feel like direct Pokémon clones, because they aren’t. They’re their own thing that was never done again.
(Except it had already been done because the battle and evolution system in digimon world 2 is literally the same lol)


I think they’re cool, I hope you check ‘em out! :D

>>9544841
Since you asked, then. Mega Man games have widespread appeal for their iconic character, boss, and stage design, the ability to use boss weapons and upgrades, and arguably some of the best music of their time period. The cartoony mech style is something other platformers didn't have, maybe with the exception of Sonic but even that didn't push it as far. It was popular enough to have its own western cartoon, something that couldn't be said for most third-party games, especially Japanese ones. The 16-bit and 32-bit era only expanded things with bigger stories, more playable characters, more moves, and things like animated cutscenes. Early games spread by word of mouth while later games became even more popular through the internet. Maybe it's not for everyone, but it certainly has its level of undeniable charm and polish.

posts.com:
>>9525483
>Can someone explain to me why source code matters
If you have the source code, the nuts and bolts of how a video game is made, you can potentially create really good modding or editing tools to add on to the game. You can already do with games that don't have publicly available source codes, but with the meat and potatoes of it the possibilities are an order of magnitude greater, including the end-user possibly creating their own game with that code. This has already happened with things like Doom's source code, Quake's source code, etc. On the flipside, sometimes source codes get released (legally or otherwise) and nothing really happens because people don't care enough.
>Why don't we already have it?
Developer, software, and publisher rights. Let's say Ed Boon was the sole owner of the source code of MKII. If it was never released, it's because he didn't want it released. But let's say Ed Boon doesn't own it and the parent company to Netherealm Studios owns the MKII source code. If Ed Boon WANTED the MKII source code out there, he'd have to go through corporate, who could just say no since he doesn't own it. If he did it anyway, he could get sued into the ground.
>Have the games not been downloaded and emulated. Are we not able to see the code then, or hack it? Why not?
All source code is converted into machine code so the computer can read it. That means only the truly adept can reverse engineer a video game, and this has happened more than once.

You didn't ask but I feel like video game studios/publishers should just release source codes far more often than they do. Croteam, the developers of Serious Sam, released the source code for Serious Sam 1's engine for free. But that was in 2017 or so, so literally who the fuck cared anymore besides serious Serious Sam fanboys? Unity, Unreal, Godot, etc. have all taken off. If Croteam had released SE1 back in 2003 after The Secound Encounter came out the FPS landscape might have been different.

Why DO all the characters in MK (visually) have the same normals anyway? In a game with traditional graphics they'd have characters with the same moves and similar outfits to save on labor by editing one character to create the other (draw a Ryu sprite then change the head and colors to make it Ken, many such cases). But in MK they weren't drawing anything, they were just filming actors on a blue screen, so they could have had them all do different moves and it wouldn't have been any more work. They threw away visual variety that they could have had for free.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525483
The ROM image contains "low level" machine code that is run directly on the CPU. Programmers write in a highly level code, like C (higher level languages you may have heard of are C#, JavaScript, Python, Java, etc., but old school arcade games never used these as they needed to be more optimised for performance) school, which goes through a "compilation" process to turn it into machine code. The code written by the programmer is the source code, and you can't directly extract this from the compiled machine code. Writing in Assembly is as close to machine code as you can get, but even then, there are comments in the file and descriptive names for variables that are lost in the compilation process. Decompilation projects manually review all the compiled code and try to recreate what they think the source code would have looked like before it was compiled. This can be verified, to a degree, by compiling the manually decompiled code and seeing if it matches the ROM, but all the identifier names and any programmer comments cannot be derived from the ROM image.

>>9525592
The way source code functions as a part of the final end product of a finished game, is that all of the human-readable code has been converted into machine language. Operating instructions for the system to perform mathematical instructions and moving memory around. This is the reason why we can't just "crack" the source code out of a game. The Mario 64 decomp devs actually went through every single instruction and deduced their purposes on a larger scale in a ridiculously difficult and drawn out process using emulators and debuggers.

It is NOT easy. Pic is "source" code. You cannot run this through a converter and spit out legible code.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9525706
Simply put, compiling takes source code/instructions written by humans, for humans, and translates/compiles it into something made to be interpreted by a machine.
For example, going from something like the C programming language, to potentially an intermediate representation (like assembly or something else), and ultimately always ends up as machine code.
So you have something high level that makes sense to a human like `print("hello")` boil down to many assembly instructions `mov x y; inc a; ...` down to even more machine instructions expressed as binary (usually rendered to humans as hex) `0x07; 0x6F; 0x32 ...`.

Decompiling is that process in reverse, and worse, it's lossy.
Documentation for the code, written as comments in the human readable source, can't be restored since it gets discarded during compilation (the machine doesn't need these, only humans do). Likewise with function and variable names (usually).
You have to read the opcodes for the machine (from the binary file) and try to deduce what could have produced that sequence of operations.
What function(s) could compile into this specific sequence?
Functions plural because multiple high level concepts can compile down to the same instructions, so even if you find an answer, it may not be the original answer.
Almost like an algebra problem, but worse. y + x = 7, what is x and y? 5 and 2? 4 and 3?

The only thing you can really do is get close approximations, and test them. Did my function compile to the same bytes? Does it "match"?

See also: https://arstechnica.com/gaming/2020/05/beyond-emulation-the-massive-effort-to-reverse-engineer-n64-source-code/

Just as with high level languages, you build up and accrue abstractions over time. I mean that both on a personal and project level. You also don't have a lot of the extra bullshit to deal with like an OS or VMM so you can greatly reduce and simplify what you even need to build and deal with in the first place. You write what you want, how you want to , with the only limits being the target machine itself.
Consider something as simple as loading data from a constant address versus making multiple syscalls to deal with some general purpose file system.

MK is just simple fun to me. It's not a "deep" fighter and some say that's why it's bad, but that's part of the appeal. When somebody speaks about "source code", they usually mean code coming from a dev that is cleanly written in a way that other humans with programming knowledge can understand, this makes it much more easy to modify for hacks, ports and what not.

Yes, there are tools to partially or completely see the code from a ROM, the problem is said code looks like an unintelligible mess since it doesn't keep any comments or the given names for variables, functions, etc. Some hackers can work with that mess and slowly figure out what is what by trial and error, the end result would be something very close to the official dev source code, but it takes too much time, guess work and autism, and there's still a chance for inaccuracies, therefore, having the official code from a dev is always more convenient than try to reverse engineer it yourself, unfortunately since it has to come from an official source and may be illegal to share, it's very rare for one to come out, so it's a big deal when one does get released. At least if it's from a game people give a shit about.

Fair enough, but the way some stuff is being shown in Retrotech videos is misleading at best. I'm not saying he's doing it in bad faith, it's just that the way it's sold can induce unecessary panic in people that don't know better. I think he has a lot of very useful practical knowledge about fixing CRTs, but he should know when he's out of his depth on technical matters and just flat out tell people: "look, I'm not exactly sure about this but this is what I think is going on" or something along those lines. He clearly lacks knowledge about some of the details of how the electronic circuitry actually works. There's no shame in that, just be honest.

>>9516704
You can clean mold off VHS tapes. Open top case of VCR. Fast forward the tape. As its running, lightly press Qtip dipped in rubbing alcohol against the capstan so the tape runs across it. Cleans all the mold off. I've done it several times and saved some rare tapes this way.

rgb's only necessary if you think it is. composite's ok if you're ok with it. rgb makes the video signal cleaner so you don't get certain video artifacts that you do with composite. some people actually prefer composite because of those artifacts. the only time rgb might be "necessary" is if the console or whatever only outputs rgb (i can't think of any examples of this, maybe there's a computer like this) or if there's some detail you can't make out on composite, which might be discernible on rgb but it could just be that the screen itself can't resolve the detail (because of dot pitch or convergence or what have you).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9536724
To properly diagnose this, open the TV up and get a blowdrier. Heat up the big capacitors near the power board until they're about as warm as lukewatm water. If you switch the tv on and it turns on instantly it's definitely bad caps. Any bulging caps are certainly bad. Replace those with caps of the same voltage and capacity (seen as uf or mf commonly.) This isn't a critical problem, but it will slowly add wear and tear to the circuitry if you don't replace caps.

Here's what I don't understand about this thread. So help me out here.

Do you people push CRTs because you think they are superior to LCDs, and refuse to change?

Or

Do you people push CRTs because you have old equipment that simply isn't compatible with new LCDs TVs (like an old NES or SNES) without an adapter?

I work for a fairly busy independently owned arcade/family fun bar and we have a mix of CRT arcade games and newer LCD arcade games.

We do repairs on the older arcade CRT games, but parts are getting harder to acquire. I would like to preserve the original design of these machines as they were made from the arcade factory. I want people to experience what it was like when these machines came out in the 80s and 90s.

However....for some broken machines we can't find the original arcade monitors anymore. Or some of the machines just can't quite stand up to the heavy usage they once did back in the 90s and constantly go down for maintenance. Usually the issues revolve around the CRT monitors.

We are thinking about adapting old CRT TVs as replacement arcade monitors. But based on what we're reading some people expressed that this isn't the way to go. That it's a janky way of doing it, and not reliable.

A new debate has started between the the arcade techs, owners, etc. Basically if we are going to all this trouble of Trying to adapt CRT TVs for arcade use, then maybe we should just use replacement LCD panels instead and maybe find a way to use a scanline filter to try to get close to the CRT look.

The argument is that "Its better to have people play these games even with an LCD compared to constantly having games go down due to CRT issues. Thar LCDs would solve 90% of the problems."

Others have said it's better to preserve the original condition from the factory or try to. Use CRTs.

I can see both arguments. What are your thoughts? We are not located in the United States. So replacement parts for us is hard to get and shipping costs can get costly

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Fundamentally different implementation of 3D
Rather than just taking a bunch of triangles that are twisted and turned to make a 3D shape they used something called NURBS. This approach comes from the CAD software that 3D modelling workstations were originally meant to run, and to this day is still used for high-accuracy CAD work.
However as real-time 3D accelerators are meant specifically for polygons those are used in games instead. You'll see a lot of NURBS models used in PS1-era FMVs as those were often made on SGI workstations that were optimized for this kind of workload.

>>9537436
This comment puts it in too simple terms, but basically gets it. The people who were producing basically any kind of visuals that are now considered the peak of "soulful" and "retro" graphics, were just extremely talented and disciplined people working within the limitations of older software/hardware. Retro fags like us who recognize the aesthetic appeal of that time are appreciating all these things in a completely different context. So when modern indie devs go for that look, they can usually recreate the technical limitations and specifics, but lack the top-of-the-line skill and the time-specific mindsets of those eras. An overblown example for comparison would be a modern archeologist trying to recreate ancient egyptian sculpture. He could get the tech down through research, but there's no way to recreate the mindset and education of those ancient artists.

>>9537435
The hell are you talking about? Sounds like you're confusing NURBS with a combination of subdivision modeling and path tracing. NURBS are mostly used for static models in industrial/design settings. All of the 90's/80's CGI videos (such as those posted by the OP) were done with graphics that used normal polygon meshes (usually subdivided), textured and prerendered with pathtracing. You cannot rig and animate an organic, strechable object like a horse or a humanoid with NURBS. You also cannot texture it with much freedom.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think we eventually will but it won't come from any big industry, probably will spring from a savant or team of savants that have to develop their own engine etc. To make it work. A lot goes into it and the mainstream video game industry isn't about to take the time and cost to make that vision a reality when selling mediocrity to people who grew up in a world where mediocrity was not only accepted but celebrated on a global scale makesnmoney hand over fist vs. any attempt at genuine artistry.
Just within those first two webms it occurred to me, for instance, how much of what people see in their heads as "that 90s CG look" has to do with the desaturating effect of being displayed on old analog tech and how VHS and old school video encoding (I'm intuiting that last part and may well be full of shit on that, autists feel free to correct me because the specifics do matter) desaturates the image and that's not inconsequential to the presentation. Were those same clips crystal clear HD I do not think they would be satisfying in the same way. It's not what people picture in their heads, they envision the imperfections as part of the medium.
There's also different forms of it, like that other anon who sounds more knowledgable than me said, this stuff was made using NURBS, and I don't believe that's the same tech as what was used to create the aesthetic of N64 era box art CG, I think all of that style boils down to being rendered on period specific SGI workstation hardware.
I feel like we'll get there by a small group of true blue autists, the kind that truly are mentally set apart to accomplish tasks otherwise infeasible, will make it their goal to either emulate or recreate that technology for the pure sake of preserving the ability to do so, and then a lesser group of passionate individuals will take that work and make games with it. That's my prediction. If not that then I think we will probably reach our tech asymptote pretty soon and it will make the task trivial.

Even back in the day, memorable individual characters had to be pretty special to easily emote, like Hexadecimal from Reboot.

There's also the, ya know, over 20 years of traction that 2D pixel art has gained notoriety for since 3D "took its place". People have been making pixel art themselves for a long time and uploading it on the net. There's been a lot of time for people to recognize that your average SNES game looked better than your average PSX game because 3D came too soon. Your average indy developer is a product of this and focused a lot of their free time creative habits on 2D, not 3D.

Also, something else has to be brought up concerning what people have said about talent. The reality is that artists have way less say in how a video game turns out as compared to other people, especially if its a project where you're doing a lot of the development work yourself (using very little frameworks or middleware). The average artist has no idea how to get the weapon effects in Amid Evil to work like they do, and they didn't back in the day, either. The people working on the engine create those kinds of visual effects.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
No self respecting artist wants to intentionally recreate something that looked like complete dog-ass.

Artists want to push boundaries and do the best they can with the available tools. That's what this art style was originally born of- It was the best they could do with the limitations of the time. They were learning as they worked, pioneering into something totally new.

Even if a modern artist wanted to work within the technical limitations of the time, for whatever reason, they still wouldn't recreate something that looks like 90s CG did. They would work differently, they would have access to greater resources, they'd have the accumulated knowledge of 20 years of progress, and they'd make something that looks better.

You are nostalgic for this stuff because it is evocative of a specific period you remembe fondly. But an artist will always strive to create the best they can with their tools. Nostalgia on it's own is a shit reason to make shitty art, so even if you crave that specific flavour of shitty art more than anything, it's likely to stay in it's time. Where it belongs. And where it should be respected.

“Whatever you now find weird, ugly, uncomfortable and nasty about a new medium will surely become its signature. The thing people are talking about with nurbs etc is, parts of the model aren't specified by triangles they're specified by math like the tip of marios finger would be 'there's a sphere here with this radius, it stops half way and turns into a cylinder,...' then when you go to render it the image's pixel grid is laid over that and then it's simple math to say 'if I, a pixel, am here, and a sphere is centered there, then if i was a triangle on its surface i would be facing this way and since the light is there, i'm thus this color'. and mario's fingertip might get 5000 triangles but your model only specified like 10 numbers for it

The data needed wasn't much, but the generated output was into gigabytes, especially if you were doing movies. And it took hours and hours to do 1 frame. That's where the term rendering farm comes from, since you had fridge sized workstations with 64 CPUs and dozens of hdds inside processing every frame, networked together working in unison.

CGI in 90s movies took up to a year or more to render on several workstations like that.

>>9539724
>data went into
>gigabytes
I'm not sure what you're really asking when it comes to data in/out, I have never really heard things talked about in those terms. As i explained to you a pure shape doesn't need anywhere near as much data to store the model as would the same shape approximated by many triangles.
If you render a single sphere with one camera and one light (with scanline micropoly OR raytracing) your spatial 'data input' is basically
>sphere position with respect to camera x y z
>light position with respect to camera x y z
>sphere radius
>light direction
like 50 bytes or something, and you might get out a 150MB 8000x8000 .bmp file. If doing scanline, then in between, unseen by you but by the computer, yes a fuckload more memory would be used, but not at once, so you wouldn't need a gigabyte of memory to do it.
But maybe if you wanted to do your sphere real time today with the scanline algorithm, you do need gigabytes to store all the micropoly at once since you don't have time to load and unload the ones to do with different pixel blocks. Hence why UE5 is only just about able to do this today on the ps5 at 2000 lines

This is different than modelling a grey gun and then overlaying a lighter gray texture to make it look "shiny" - it's reflecting the environment. Look. I guess it would be possible to do that, constantly checking the position of the POV character against the environment and manually substituting slightly different color overlays frame by frame, but it's extremely unlikely.

>disingenous

I'm being as clear and simple as it's possible to be, anon. I'm even linking you stuff from the time period

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9539818
>I dont' want to wade in between you and the other anon, but that's what I'm (now) arguing what this aesthetic actually IS. It's very simple geometric shapes but rendered at *perfect* resolutions with no polygons.

That, anon, is ray tracing, especially in the 90s.

> I think even with non-ray traced lighting the aesthetic would still be there, just not as bold.

I get your meaning, and it's true, but to be pedantic remember that ray-tracing literally IS the lighting. You set the light source(s), you set the objects, you set the camera location, and then the rendering engine emits light rays from the light source, off the objects and into the camera, at whatever resolution you've got the RAM and storage for

it's pretty wild the variety of scenes you can construct using the method of rendering, especially considering that the actual geometry files for something like this was probably about 20 kilobytes and the textures not much more.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9539732
My guy, are you sure? AFAIK, scanline rendering is one of the two options (the other being Z-buffering; they are also combinable) for determining what is visible in 3D scenes - that is: determining what objects are "in front" of other objects, thus rendering them fully, and everything thats "behind" them gets renderred partially.
It has nothing to do with lighting algorithms, which are a different algorithm that can be combined with those that determine visible surface.
Although AFAIK raytracing is an umbrella term and can be used both for visible surface determining and lighting algorithms. The current Nvidia RTX stuff is a hodge-podge of partial raytracing used mostly for reflections that is then upscaled and integrated with other more "classic" realtime techniques.
But I might be wrong about some of this, so someone please correct me...

Bryce 3d and Pov-Ray are famous for being available to the larger public. The high end shit would run on SGI workstations: software packages like Softimage 3D and The Advanced Visualizer. posts.com:
Another reason that muh ray-tracing is the wrong direction to pursue when trying to reach the 90s look is that a very distinctive aspect of the renders is that light does NOT bounce, at all. If you don't have a light aimed on some part of the scene, it is BLACK.
Ray-tracing is all about bouncing rays of light and 'view' around the scene so that a bit of red from the red ball goes onto the white ground, etc. This bleed is the lighting feature that 'sells' reality to your unconscious* mind and the beauty of 90s rendering was that it DIDN'T have this 'so you knew you were in a dream'.

* i say unconscious because you don't see it until you look you just say yep that's real. look at pic related for example and now i point it out you can see a very obvious pink glow on the pillow under his face. normally you never would have seen it

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9542232
Sonic (and other Sega games like Alex Kidd, Streets of Rage with 3, etc) had a tendency to have more plot than their contemporaries at the time. The Japanese Sonic manuals always had complex stories and while they're questionable in how well they gel (especially the original implication of each island having its own set of Chaos Emeralds), they nevertheless build on what came before. Then Sonic 3 started adding story elements to the actual game, which is more obvious if you play through it as 3&K where the attempted relaunch of the Death Egg happens midway through rather than as the climax of one game.
For Sonic Adventure (which I believe was supposed to be an RPG at that), they transferred that over to the actual game as well, which basically became their style for the 3D games.
Of course, how well it works depends on your suspension of disbelief.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Metal Storm has an interesting story. Made by Japanese devs it was released in the US in 91. Then, it was finally released in Japan in 92, 14 months later.
What's even more interesting is that the internal dates in the game are 90 (US) and 91 (JPN), suggesting a long or troubled release schedule.

The Japanese version has an added intro as well as some balance and palette changes.

Despite this some people argue that the Japanese version was made first and that content was "removed" in the US version, "removed" in a version that came out more than a year before. The "proof" of this being an unused tileset in the JPN version showing "1990", despite the "1991" tiles also existing and being used.

The idea that this intro was "removed" seems really silly, especially considering it wasn't just dummied out (as if they failed to bother to translate it), entire graphics are missing (as if they weren't even made yet).
However, there are indeed other clues supporting the theory, for instance the JPN version has some extra cheat passwords, which while they don't exist in the US version, their effect are still in the code, dummied out.

I have come to the conclusion that we will never really know and that this entire way of thinking may be biaised to begin with. When a game has several versions, people often make a lot of assumptions on "which was version was made first" with little to base themselves on (for instance it used to be very common to have PAL versions released last, yet being based on an earlier build, due to the time window from Gold to Release being longer). I also found that in many cases, games weren't developped in a linear way like this kind of assumption thinks, but instead several versions/branches of the same game could be dev'd at the same time.

RetroBit released a third version of the game in 2019 which is an English translation of the JPN version.

The switch started in Sonic Adventure 1 (Sonic and co start calling him Eggman) and Sonic Adventure 2 (Robotnik starts calling himself Eggman)
By SA1, Sega started going with a unified canon rather than having Japan and the west use different canons. Thus, the Robotnik name was canonized via Maria and Gerald Robotnik in SA2, but the doctor himself was consistently named Dr. Eggman (with the in-universe justification of it either being a nickname he claimed from Sonic or an alias).

>>9535273
Also, another reason this comparison fails is because Vader is a straightforward intimidating villain.
Dr. Robotnik, outside of SatAM and some western marketing, always has a silly undercurrent. He models mechas and a space station after himself. One game has Sonic defeat him by running very fast on a treadmill. He once blew up his own ship. An animation had him ruin Sonic's reputation in response to Sonic being named Man of the Year. The first game ends with him either juggling the emeralds Sonic missed or throwing a tantrum. Even Sonic Adventure, which played him more seriously on the surface, reveals that his personal battleship has amenities like a swimming pool and a toy room.
Eggman can be threatening, as the Sonic CD futures show, and I do feel that later games go too far with making him goofy, but his menace is usually juxtopositioned with his silliness. The comparison fails because Vader is a dead serious villain outside of media that parodies Star Wars.

>>9535403
It depends. The games just vaguely kinda suggested that Eggman wanted to rule the world. Sonic CD and the Sonic Technical Files suggest that it's because Eggman felt that machines were beautiful and could be controlled, with nature being a resource at best. CD goes further to imply that Eggman could even potentially be negligent to his own machines, as his badniks are rundown in the bad future.
>The evil doctor (also known as Eggman) has been a bad egg from the very beginning. Nobody knows quite where he came from, but he is definitely behind any problem that comes up. Dr. Robotnik loves machines. He loves them so much that his idea of a perfect world would be to have it full of nothing but machines. He thinks they are beautiful and he likes that he can control them. A genuine genius megalomaniac, he spends all of his time trying to replace the natural world with his beautiful machines. He is not very concerned about saving the planet (being a notorious polluter), and he particularly likes the idea of exploiting the oceans for their riches (This really gets to Sonic, because Sonic loves the oceans and can't stand the idea of Robotnik messing with them). In order to have ultimate control in his quest, Robotnik must find and control all of the Chaos Emeralds, and most importantly.....Sonic.
Around Sonic LabyrinthSonic Adventure, they gave a more solid goal of establishing an empire with the capital of Eggmanland/Robotnikland and the "mechanizing nature" aspect took more of a backseat.

It wasn't until they were wowed by 3D graphics and real-sounding music that consoles started becoming worthwhile purchases from their perspective, and even then, only richfags bought them (especially the N64), with kids networking to get to be the ones hanging out with the console kids. Most kids had to settle for just a Game Boy to call their own. Trust me, I'm able to see the Sonic franchise from an outside perspective precisely because I was a poorfag who didn't have the money to watch the cartoons on cable TV or stuff like that.

>>9538086
So many Mario localization changes are utterly nonsensical ("Lakitu" doesn't mean a fucking thing), with Koopa --> Bowser being the worst of them. Before Super Mario Bros., the name Bowser was exclusively contextualized as a generic name for a pet dog in America. The whole arrangement is like if Hitler were renamed Fido, the SS were called Hitler Footlers, and good/neutral German characters in RPG spinoffs were called things like Hitla, Hits, and Hitomi. In games with more atypical localizations, like Super Mario RPG, they already blurred the lines between regions; a simple green Koopa shell is called a Noknok (Nokonoko) Shell, as it is in the original Japanese. I'm sure you're all familiar with SMB3 retaining Kuribo's Shoe and Jugem's Cloud. The changes were ultimately unnecessary and simply a product of their time.

"Goomba" is also worth mentioning as a particularly stupid localization. The original term applies more to Mario and Luigi than it does to the mushroom enemies. If Super Mario Bros. debuted today, there's no way they'd have changed the names like this. The older I get, the more it bothers me.

If there was a PC source port you can combine the best of the PlayStation and Saturn versions to make an ultimate hybrid.
From Sony:
>the extra jump button (srsly why wasn't the Saturn controller better utilized?)
>better audio and FMV quality overall (maybe hand-pick the few things that are supposedly better on Saturn, like Aqua Man's stage theme)
From Sega:
>extra enemy placements only help an already easy game (MAYBE just get rid of the first two enemies being Mets or at least move them later in the level since that seems remarkably lazy, like "oh boy we gotta have em it's a Mega Man game," plus it frankly spoils the mood of the first enemy being a surprise turret supposed to be set in a covert base)
>instead of Duo's stage reusing the opening stage theme, have it use Saturn Tengu Man's stage theme - it's short enough and fits SO much better there (MAYBE keep the flash when you enter, but ONLY have it sound ONCE as an atmospheric effect for the first screen transition inside, otherwise it badly drowns the music)
>graphical alterations: use the additional hologram background effect in Astro Man's battle transitions, and the orange Robot Master name font because pink is overused; DON'T use the water effect due to potentially hindering spike-section gameplay, or the pixel-different HUD icon due to being pointless.
>keep Cutman and Woodman as bonus boss fights with the following changes: 1) remove the badly-written pre-battle dialog, they serve no purpose and it ruins the second "oh snap" half of the music you normally only hear at Bass, 2) allow the player to refight them if the stage is selected again like any other miniboss, 3) move Woodman's location so he's now optional just like Cutman, &4) MAYBE a better reward instead of moved bolts.
>include Bonus Mode, but hide it behind Game Information and the code from Saturn credits, and upgrade quality of illustrations reused in Legacy Collection museum.
Plus things expected of a PC port like language select.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9532438
Anyone ever notice that Cut Man and Wood Man were always part of the same shot in the opening animation? It's Wood Man, Centaur Man, Spark Man, Skull Man, Gyro Man, Cut Man, and Freeze Man. These are different from the RobotMasters shown in earlier in the FMV since those were dramatized flashbacks of the original games - this is a new scene of robots from each game ganging up on Mega Man. So my theory is that Cut Man and Wood Man from the Saturn version are a remnant of a much bigger plan for the PlayStation version. I really think you were originally supposed to revisit each level ala Mega Man 3, which is why a lot of Bolts require a second visit. Recall that Mega Man 8 was supposed to be the 10-anniversary game. There was probably a plan to make that series celebration more evident, but things fell through.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9534810
>Honestly think this problem's overstated, but then again I never compared them back to back. I can imagine scrolling with that effect might be a problem on a crappy TV.
It's an issue in exactly one part of the game: the spike-section in the first half of Aqua Man's stage. The reason is because there's a series of spike floors and ceilings that you have to carefully navigate through. In PlayStation version, this section is easier to navigate since the visibility is perfectly clear. In Saturn version, because the long spikes are affected by the new water effect, it's inadvertently harder to determine the spike tips and platform edges, making it easier to instantly lose a life. I can attest to game-overing here on Saturn while it was a breeze on PlayStation. There are more spikes in an optional area in the second half of the level, but they're shorter, the tunnel is a lot less narrow, and there's much less going on visually, so it shouldn't be a problem there. You might be able to fix the issue by if you were to keep the water wave effect only in the background (The Wily Wars does a similar thing in Bubble Man's stage) or you leave it out of there like most Mega Man games.

>>9518605
Decompiling is a pain, and usually, you will need to sort out a lot of things by yourself.
Even if decompilers now can separate code from data (which is helped in consoles starting at PS1 gen because some sort of memory formatting was common) you will likely end up with assembly with variable and functions name meaning nothing.
Well, at least, I tried it for the game boy, and so it was.
I don't see why PS1 would be different (except maybe if they let the debug symbols on the final CD? That's not unheard of, but quite rare).

Anyways, good luck, and enjoy your project!
It you can post your advancements here, that would be really great.

What game do you want to decompile?

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9520325
The Jetsons Invasion of the Planet Pirates comes to mind.
As a licensed game developed by Taito for the SNES, they re-used the game engine and level designs for another licensed game in Japan; Youkai Buster: Ruka no Daibouken.

The game is mostly the same, but the key differences aside from the change in characters and visuals, is a different intro cutscene, the introduction of bonus levels after each action level's boss fight, a whole new final boss, and the inclusion of additional cheat codes whilst the game is paused. The game is however two levels shorter, not all levels were converted from the original game, but some mini-game segments were put in their place.

Whichever version you play though, it is a genuinely good game, nothing amazing, but worth a play.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9531151
First, take a crash course in electronics circuits.
Then, build a transiver from 5V to 3.3V.
I think the best way to do it would be to use an ESP32 with WiFi.
Then, code some kind of API (check if extension is present, init, get access point list, connect to one, send a request, receive an answer, etc.
Then, code the software (and if you ant it to be useful, think of it as a project using a lib. Like, don't do some URL check or whatever in the game code.)
Lastly, enjoy!
I would start super simple with a game that just check if the extension is plugged.
An other on that does that and list the networks and their strength.
Lastly, one that goes and fetch a text file somewhere on the internet.

As for the hardware, I don't know what buses the NES have exposed. Maybe the same as cartridges? If so, you are midly fucked. You expansion may present as a RAM page, where you write at some addresses, and it gives you answers at other addresses?

>Are there any NES games that make use of the "illegal opcodes" I hear exist in the 6502?
"Games using unofficial opcodes

The use of unofficial opcodes is rare in NES games. It appears to occur mostly in late or unlicensed titles:

Beauty and the Beast (E) (1994) uses $80 (a 2-byte NOP).[2]
Disney's Aladdin (E) (December 1994) uses $07 (SLO). This is Virgin's port of the Game Boy game, itself a port of the Genesis game, not any of the pirate originals.
Dynowarz: Destruction of Spondylus (April 1990) uses 1-byte NOPs $DA and $FA on the first level when your dino throws his fist.
F-117A Stealth Fighter uses $89 (a 2-byte NOP).
Gaau Hok Gwong Cheung (Ch) uses $8B (XAA immediate) as a 2-byte NOP. The game malfunctions after selecting Left from the main menu if that instruction is not emulated.
Infiltrator uses $89 (a 2-byte NOP).
Puzznic (all regions) (US release November 1990) uses $89 (a 2-byte NOP).
Super Cars (U) (February 1991) uses $B3 (LAX).

Homebrew games

The MUSE music engine, used in Driar and STREEMERZ: Super Strength Emergency Squad Zeta, uses $8F (SAX), $B3 (LAX), and $CB (AXS).[3]
Attribute Zone uses $0B (ANC), $2F (RLA), $4B (ALR), $A7 (LAX), $B3 (LAX), $CB (AXS), $D3 (DCP) and $DB (DCP).
The port of Zork to the Famicom uses a few unofficial opcodes."
From: https://www.nesdev.org/wiki/CPU_unofficial_opcodes

posts.com: Which number gets minused from which number when running a comparison like this?
posts.filename: Screenshot 2023-01-05 at 06-44-14 Famicom Party 11. More Assembly Branching and Loops

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9543408
the compare instructions (CMP / CPX / CPY) perform a "subtraction" without affecting the accumulator, register or memory in question, only setting the carry (C), negative (N) and zero (Z) flags. its the immediate or memory value that gets subtracted from the register, which is (A - V / X - V / Y - V) respectively.
this allows you to use branch instructions to dictate the flow of your code, for example: BCC jumps if the value is less than the compare, BEQ jumps if the value is equal to the compare, and BCS jumps if the value is greater OR EQUAL to the compare.
https://www.masswerk.at/6502/6502_instruction_set.html#CMP
also, circumstances willing, it's more efficient to decrement your loops to 0 and have the DEC instruction before the branch, eliminating the need for a compare as DEC will still set the zero and negative flags for BNE (or BPL for a loop cycle when the value is zero) but don't worry about that for now

posts.com:
My quest to play as many RPGs as I can on NES/Famicom continues. While I prioritize classic turned based RPGs, once in a while I play hybrid games as long as they're turned based and the occasional A-RPG. Here is the latest I played and a few words

>Gegege no Kitarou 2 - Youkai Gundan no Chousen (Spooky Kitaro 2 - Kitaro Versus Yokai Army)

For 1987 excellent combat: great graphics (backgrounds + characters on the same screen in a very smart way), very dynamic with movement and projectiles when attacking.
The game is properly balanced for the first half (a bit challenging) but max level is reached half way through the game, from that point onwards there is no point in fighting random encounters anymore. Also, a couple of cryptic stuff to progress through the game despite the in game clues.
posts.filename: Gegege no Kitarou 2 - Youkai Gundan no Chousen (Spooky Kitaro 2 - Kitaro Versus Yokai Army)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Cleopatra no Mahou (The Cursed Treasure of Cleopatra)

A somewhat short adventure/RPG by Square, one of the last games they made before Nasir joined them and they made Final Fantasy. Very simple both in terms of adventure and RPG elements although there had to be one clue-less item puzzle required to progress.
Still managed to grab my attention, nice graphics. A bit grindy.
posts.filename: Cleopatra no Mahou (The Cursed Treasure of Cleopatra)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Kawa no Nushi Tsuri (Legend of the River King)

Fishing/RPG hybrid. The game is all about grind. You grind the fish?ing segment for money, and you grind the turned based RPG battles with random encounter to level up as all the wild life in the entire world is out to kill you, from rats to bears. Then you can reach the next section and repeat while upgrading your fishing equipments on the way and solving the occasional simple item puzzle. Very repetitive but I understand this double grind to be someone's idea of relaxing, and it spawned an entire series.
I found two main flaws: one, the best way to make money seems to be right at the start of the game, at least once you get a middle class rod, so I found it best to backtrack there every time I needed money. Two, the only way to regain two of the five bait types (including the most important one required to beat the game) seems to be to use a password.
posts.filename: Kawa No Nushi Tsuri (Legend of the River King)

posts.com:
>Dai 2 Ji Super Robot Taisen (Super Robot Wars 2)

Tactics game with exp/lvl-up and a shop system. Basically Fire Emblem with mecha robots from manga and anime. I know nothing about any of the source material. Each unit is unique and behaves differently, plus most of them have several variants, either transformations you can switch to at any time to get the best of any situation or upgrades along the game. This is where the game shines as each unit/character is truly unique.
Unlike FE, the shop system is basically inexistant/irrelevant which is somewhat a relief if you've played FE1 and like me had to spend hours micro managing items, however money is also used to repair defeated units at the end of a mission and this is where the player needs to be careful. There are 26 missions, about the same as FE1. Difficulty seemed really easy, definitely easier than the two Famicom Fire Emblem.
posts.filename: Dai 2 Ji Super Robot Taisen (Super Robot Wars 2)

>>9543201
Outside of the usual DQ/FF, which are undeniably some of the bests jRPGs on the system (my personal favourite being DQ2 and FF2, which should give you an idea of my taste), the best I've played so far are Earthbound Beginnings, Digital Devil Story Megami Tensei II and Metal Max.
Every once in a while in my daily file I find myself randomly thinking about Metal Max 1 and Metal Max 2 on SFC and how good those games made me feel.

Outside of that the most underrated game one I've played so far is probably Namco's Dream Master, which is a hybrid adventure/RPG game that plays a lot like Sweet Home in many ways. Then you have the DQ clones I really liked like Ninjara Hoi!, SD Keiji - Blader and Jubei Quest, but they're not something I'd recommend to someone before many others.

The worst is Bloody Warriors Shan Go, the game is basically a tech demo that one would pitch to a publisher in order to try and make a real game. Then I really disliked LaSalle Ishii no Child's Quest and Destiny of an Emperor, that last one probably being the only hot take I have considering how famous the game seems to be in the US (imo only because it's one of the few that got officially released)

Also I really liked Dragon Ball 2 as well, which is an adventure/RPG/card hybrid game. For a supposed licenced shovelware game that only lasts a few hours I thought it was really good and I'm not even such a big fan of the franchise. Shame DB3 hasn't been translated. In comparison I played all the DBZ games as well (all 4 of them though the last one doesn't count as RPG) and I thought they were only okay despite the awesome presentation

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9544074
I played them all except Metal Saga on DS and Xeno. 1 and 2 remain my favourites, and the more time passes and the more I think 2 was stellar.

Returns was great, I especially liked the new content and being able to use it to sequence break.

Saga on PS2 has a great world and interesting changes to the gameplay, however balance is whack and the game is too easy. Due to how the exp/lvl system works it is way too easy to gain a couple of levels and find yourself untouchable just because you walked a few steps into the other direction. Also, battle speed (especially due to animation) is extremely slow, I shit you not some enemies attack like those balloon soldiers take up to 30 seconds (and of course you get several enemies per turn)

Then there are 3, 2:R and 4 which all belong in the same style of visuals and gameplay. Their strength come from the tons of content and replay value, and you will always find a way to break the game in a ridiculous fashion if you look.
I thought something was lost in those 3 games though, in the previous ones there was a balance between despair in a post apocalyptic world and lightheartedness. In 2R, 3 and 4 I do not know where the despair has gone to, replaced by whacky stuff.

I do not speak Japanese so for 2 on SNES and 4 I used Retroarch AI translate tool which worked okay for the most part (better for 4 than 2) if only that it requires patience. I think 4 is being translated though. I couldn't do that for Saga on DS because that game is touchscreen only and for some reasons the mouse for emulating touchscreen is completely offset for me in retroarch

>>9543329
> (my personal favourite being DQ2 and FF2, which should give you an idea of my taste)

Nice fellow ff2 enjoyer, I played DQ2 a few years back and didn't complete it because the last dungeon and boss were too bullshit for me, with its unlimited capacity to full heal. I weighed up the choice between spending several more hours grinding levels and still relying on luck to get through, or just moving on to playing something else, and decided on the latter. I really enjoyed it up until the very last part, though. I'm now playing through DQ3 after a few years break from the series and I'm glad I don't have to fill my camera roll with passwords anymore and spend several minutes typing one in any time I play.

Have you played Niji no Silk Road/Rainbow Silk Road? Its one I'd like to try after I get through DQ3 and 4 and FF3, it sounds interesting. Enemies don't drop money or EXP, instead defeating them earns you "licence points" that give you the ability to sell more goods in different places. You basically have to be a traveling merchant across Asia, buying stuff in one place and selling it in another for profit. As you travel through desert you have to watch your water supply, and you can hire guards to help out in battle and buy animals to carry more goods.

>>9532823
There are several good ports. My personal favorite way to play is the M2 3D one on the 3ds. They did a phenomenal job and even fish in a given school are at different depths. I have played it emulated many times though with no issue.

I do recommend a guide if you feel stuck, there are two quests near the beginning where you rescue lost dolphins and those give you very useful abilities for the rest of the game.

Finally though, if you find yourself very stuck or the game is too hard, or you just want to play it more casually, all versions including the GBA port have the debug code which is quite robust.

You can yourself invulnerable if you want, level select or teleport to any area of the current zone. Almost more fun though is you can change the music tempo which given Ecco's incredible soundtrack makes for some really cool variations you can do.

>>9532972
Good luck with it, I'm glad to help! It's one of my favorite games of all time, but I understand well why it's always been a little niche. My suggestion if you try again is just take it slow for a while and learn how the game flows. The second level has an octopus that is there to help teach you. You'll feel low on air and like you should be rushing, but the octopus will slap you back of you do. In Ecco, rushing is what usually kills you. Your air is always depleting and you will think you're going to drown if you don't, but success relies on keeping calm under pressure and being accurate. Many people say it's crazy hard, but really outside of the Asterite fight and the Vortex queen at the end, it's really not that difficult ot just takes a kind of mentality that most games don't require as much.
