>>9535508
I actually saw it from a totally different perspective, to me it was like "hmmmm never seen this kinda stuff before.."
lets not forget that most of the "sister games" back then were just Barbie crap. back then a Dolphin on the cover did not automatically give people the feeling of it being a kids game, hell the Genesis was even marketed as a console for dudebros way before the xbox360 coined that phrase.
back then most of us just didn't even feel like we could be subjected to kids games on the Genesis, Snes for sure cuz Nintendo. but Genesis just felt differently.
you saw Toejam & Earl and you didn't think "oh kiddy alien game" no you thought "wow, thats a whacky bro experience!"

Even now when I go through my rom collection and find stuff like Richard Scarry's Busytown it feels.. off somehow. as in "this shouldn't be on the Genesis"
That's just how it was marketed, even Lion King and Aladdin didn't feel like they were for kids, they were for all ages.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9535820
>It's not something like Space Harrier or Streets of Rage that you can play and even if it kicks your ass, still have fun with the pacing

See I guess I just don't see it that way. While I love Space Harrier to a huge degree, I also like Ecco. They are very different, but I don't see that as a bad thing. I hate this comparison being thrown around, but in many ways Ecco is like Demon's Souls was compared to other contemporary games.

From an objective standpoint there are many harder retro games, Ninja Gaiden, Castlevania 3, Super Ghouls n Ghosts, Battletoads, 1ccing Gradius etc (all of which get regular threads here by people declaring that the difficulty is overstated) are all much harder than anything Ecco throws at you, even the last levels. Most games, especially platformers have similar enough controls that you tangentially get good at others while playing it. With Ecco, nothing else plays like it so you're also learning a whole new control scheme.

However, all those games have a similar flow which is much more action focused. Ecco is all about being careful, scoping out the environment with your sonar and clearing an area of enemies so when you have to rush through you can. It's very different from many other console games of the era, but I don't see that as a bad thing.

>>9536263
It's really not a handwave, it's how the game is designed. You can call it tedious, but it was never meant to be a bing bing wahoo rush to the finish type game. Unreliable just makes no sense, if you want to permakill an enemy, you can. It's about making the decision you want to.

Again as I always say in these threads, since first playing Ecco has always been in my top selection of games and I almost always have a playthrough on the go somewhere. Along with that love is the understanding it doesn't appeal to everyone, but I don't see that as a bad thing. Games should appeal to many different people.

>>9544146
Playing SM64 on modern devices can actually feel clunky due to how the original N64 controller was designed.
The analogue stick has a huge pivot that allows for much finer sensitivity. The developers intended for you to have that finesse in movement, like when you need to walk slowly on a treacherous narrow path. That's especially prominent in Tiny Huge Island.

Most modern game controllers have a much smaller pivot on analogue sticks, and N64 emulators don't seem to compensate for it, even in official Nintendo products and services like Super Mario 3D All-Stars or the Nintendo Switch Online version.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think that out of all super heroes, Spider-Man is the one that's got the better treatment from video games, of course that perception changed over time due to Batman getting his well received Arkham series in the last decade, but before that it was pretty much unanimous that Spider-Man had the best video game career out of all super heroes. I remember playing Spider-Man: Return of the Sinister Six as a kid, it was my first ever experience with a video game based on my favorite super hero, and it was quite good, nothing superb, but it doesn't deserve the poor reception it usually gets, it plays fine enough and has some good level design.

What I really remember from my childhood however, is the PS1 duology of Spider-Man and Spider-Man 2: Enter Electro. I couldn't believe how accurate these were, you really felt like you were Spider-Man, and the jump to 3D helped with that quite a lot. I recall growing up and hoping that there'd be a 3rd installment, but there wasn't, the Sam Raimi films came out and, while I loved those, and both Spider-Man (PS2) and Spider-Man 2 (PSP) played like the PS1 duology, it wasn't set in the same universe... lately I discovered something though, the PS1 original was ported to GBC, which got a sequel... and a 3rd installment, Mysterio's Menace.

When I finally looked at Mysterio's Menace it really took me by surprise, the graphics, UI, power ups... everything seemed like the PS1 duology, and that's because, from what I've read, this is a sequel to that, and not the GBC timeline, regardless if that's the case or not, it sure feels like it. I've just finished a playthrough on Easy and, while nowhere near the experience I got from the PS1 duology, it feels quite good, and it's worthy of the classics I grew up with, the 3rd installment I always wanted. Well then, what are you experiences with Spider-Man video games? I know there are lots of them, good and bad, a lot of memories we can talk about.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9542261
A little update. I still haven't been able to get everything in Spider-Man: Mysterio's Menace, the upgrades are a challenge to find, I've only got a couple so far, but it's fun to explore the levels while looking for these things. Anyway, I did just finish a playthrough on Normal difficulty, so Super Hero is all that remains, besides doing it 100% of course, though I won't be too harsh on myself if I don't pull it off, there are a few Spider-Man video games where I wanted 100% completion and gave up, like Spider-Man on PS1 due to the Quick-Change suit being impossible to get, and 8bit Spider-Man vs. The Kingpin for having 1 life.

I still have a smile on my face, as this feels like the 3rd installment to the PS1 duology that I've wanted through out my entire childhood, the graphics and UI are clearly based on it, it can't be a coincidence. Vicarious Visions did a good job here, just like they did in Spider-Man 2: Enter Electro, though neither is as good as Neversoft's original, and from the trilogy I'd say this is the worst one... I think Spider-Man can work well in 2D, but this feels like the 3D PS1 duology, just with a dimension less, so it's simply lesser by default, still good, but not as good. I do feel that this is a worthy ending to the series I loved on the PS1 though.

Of course there are things that bother me, Spider-Man really needed more invincibility frames after getting hit, and enemies can have life bars that are too large at times, or just have a very cheap placement overall, especially on the edge of platforms you have to jump on... either way, level design is still good and varied for the most part, interesting to navigate in and explore, I also love the controls, it doesn't feel as good as 16bit Spider-Man vs. The Kingpin to me, but it does feel good overall, and it's a good translation of the PS1 control scheme. Next is difficulty Super Hero, and 100% completion, hopefully I can pull it off soon.

>>9535790
It just overwrites a bunch of values in memory. Basically most things like player health etc. are stored as variables in RAM. The gameshark overwrites the values to "fool" the game.

posts.com:

I was talking about more specifically, as in, if I wanted to override the timer value for a demo how the in the good fuck would I go about doing that?

Is it a simple thing to do with tutorials? I mean I know it’s 25 years too late for it to be relevant, but it’d still be pretty interesting to find out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9538312
Find the part of the memory that stores the timer value. Set it to biggest allowed integer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9537609
nice

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9539240
Or:
>change the decrement amount on the timer to 0
>change the timer check to always return as true (or false, depending on which one triggers the time-over)
>NOP the jump operation to the timer function

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Since they're both known for branching out into many different genres, a good way to compare them would be to look at how well they performed in each one.
>Platformer
This is a hard one, but I give it to Konami. If you look beyond their flagship series in the genre, Konami minus Castlevania is a stronger library than Capcom minus Mega Man.
>2D Shooter
Konami
>Third-Person Shooter
Capcom
>Fighting
Capcom
>RPG
The Breath of Fire games, as a whole, are better than the Suikoden series so Capcom. And this isn't getting into shit like Battle Network.
>Horror
Another tough one but I say Capcom. Konami really only has about 4 or 5 good horror games while Capcom has at least twice as many.
>Beat 'em Up
Capcom
>Racing
Konami
>Hack 'n Slash
Capcom
>Stealth
Konami
>Adventure
Konami
>Action-Adventure
Capcom
>Music
Konami
>Sports
Konami
>Strategy/Tactics
Konami

That's 8 for Konami, 7 for Capcom. Konami are the true virtuoso of video games, in the retro era at least.

The issue was more that Sega was hemorrhaging money to keep the thing going. The system was being sold at a massive loss to keep it's hype going and while software attach rates were good, they weren't anywhere near where they needed to be to make up for that massive loss.

When this was going on CD Burners still weren't common, so piracy wasn't an issue yet. However if Sega kept going with it it would have became a problem because you had about 10 Million Dreamcast owners out there who could just burn a CD of their game and play it. And that terrified developers and publishers.

>>9526672
It was always a tech demo
VF1: just its existence was revolutionary, from the system to the models. Hair and cloth physics, even animated faces.
VF2: texture-mapping
VF3: eye-tracking, more dynamic faces, hair and cloth physics expanded upon, uneven stages and dodge button
VF4: first 3DFG with customization and an online service (arcade only), introduced side-stepping, breakable walls, one stage had a snowy floor and another a watery floor
VF5: Ultimate was done in the Dragon engine, but that's all I remember

>>9526773
>>>9526767 (You)
>>saturn
>Arcade version is better I only have the PSN version of it because I started the series a little later


The framerate was one of the big improvements that Virtua Fighter 2 made over Virtua Fighter 1. The first game still looked incredible for a 1993 release, but it is still the slowest playing of the Virtua Fighter series. Kinda like how Street Fighter 1 ran at a low framerate. All of the home ports of Virtua Fighter 1 are locked down to 30fps. The 32x game retains 30fps for the majority of the game, but has some slowdown during the win/ lose cutscenes. One of the big enhancements that the model 2 arcade board made was the 60 (57fps) framerate. Every Model 2 arcade game targeted 57fps. Though the Saturn and many of the home ports (Excluding the Genesis port) run at a slightly higher framerate than the arcade game at a real 60fps.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ojLtum_HYAc

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9526810
>>Though the Saturn and many of the home ports (Excluding the Genesis port) run at a slightly higher framerate than the arcade game at a real 60fps.
>Oh. I still like the arcade one better because the backgrounds are 3D rather than sprites.

The Saturn version is still great, and even has the 2.1 arcade updates. It plays incredibly close to the arcade game. But it is misisng the polygon backgrounds. The Saturn game was also ported to Windows 95 back in the day, and the Windows 95 port looks just like the saturn game, but has the option for D3D rendering and you can use the arcade models instead. I feel like the XBLA port was one of the best versions (It is also on PSN?, but I have never played that one)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NGHJHq0oHw8
This one has the arcade visuals, but runs at a higher resolution than the arcade game, and also 60fps.

The arcade model 2 board does not run at 60fps due to some sort of limitations of the board. It's really 57fps, but when used with the right type of CRT display, you don't really notice. But 57fps would look janky on LED's, so many of the later VF2 home ports are set to 60 for consistencies sake.

>>complains when character design is grounded

That is the weird thing about Virtua fighter. The characters are tempered (somewhat), but there are still these game like elements. Like Sarah being the blonde brainwashed assassin trope. battle Arena did kind of the same thing with Sonya. Nina is the blonde brainwashed assassin type in Tekken. Why was that a thing in 3D fighters? Akira kinda being the series Ryu, though even more boring. Jackie looks like a Ken clone, but is more like Sarah. Jeffrey is oddly more original characters. Pai is teen idol trope. Lau Chan is/ was an antagonist to Akira. Maru is mysterious ninja trope. Shun Di = drunken old man (best character), Taka =- we added a Sumo wrestler. yeah, the characters are the most basic versions of tropes. DOA goes in the complete opposite, but still features all the same tropes. It's hard to fault anyone that says they are kinda dull. But oddly done that way by design. the characters in the games are best defied by their move sets/ fighting styles. They do try to go for some authentic fighting moves, for each character.

06 has THE BEST duel puzzles ever, they're really challenging but also very fair. I finally beat all of them on my last playthrough and it was one of the most satisfying and pleasurable experiences I've ever had in a Yu-gi-oh game.

And it was one of my favorite games when I was a kid.
Those are my reasons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541114
I wouldn't say there is a best one, OP. All of them are quite different from one another, so it really depends on what you're looking for. I think the 1st distinction that needs to be made is between the installments that follow the official rules, like all of the WC installments, alongside EDS and SDD, and the ones that follow the old GB/GBC rules like Sacred Cards and Reshef of Destruction. If we go for the latter, the main difference between them is difficulty, if you want something smooth, go for Sacred Cards, if you want to tear your hair out, go for Reshef of Destruction, either way both of them have an open map you can explore, kind of like Pokémon, but on a smaller scale. Now, for the installments that follow the rules, if you want an open map like in the installments I've mentioned, go for WC2005:7 Trials of Glory, but if you want a bunch of duels one after another without much in between, go for EDS, WC2004 or WC2006, SDD has an attempt at making the Battle City story, and GX Duel Academy is more open, but navigation is through menus. Overall it also depends on what era of Yu-Gi-Oh! you're more into, the original or GX, and what time frames within those eras you prefer, with different ban lists and stuff.

>>9541114
Really depends on what you actually want from a Yugioh game. If you want the actual card game then WC06.

If you still want to play the card game with a more story-based experience (I'm using that term lightly here) then either GX Duel Academy or Stairway to the Destined Duel.

If you want a more traditional card game RPG then Sacred Cards. If you just want the Yugioh characters without having to play Yugioh then there's Destiny Board Traveler and Dungeon Dice Monsters.

Objectively WC06 is probably the best *Yugioh* game, but again it just depends on what you want.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9543523
It's a lot easier to convey if someone has stopped moving, if everyone regularly moves by just flipping the sprite back and forth, at least for sprites facing downwards.

In the immediate starting town of Koholint Island in Link's Awakening, NPC animation is conveyed multiple ways:
>Child's front facing sprite flips back and forth automatically,
>Mother holding child, old lady, old man in rocking chair, mutts, cuccos, have two or three frames of animation that play automatically
>Butterfies have a very simple graphic that flips vertically to convey flapping
>Some NPCs will follow the player's movement and turn/flip to face them
>Pair of children playing by throwing a ball back and forth, consisting of two frames of animation, but the child waiting to receive will jump up and down with a visible ground shadow, the ball also casts a shadow

For the simplicity of it, it achieves a lot in making the game feel alive, even if most NPCs stay anchored to their position.

Bow Wow, the chain chomp, is one of the more complex animations, especially as you take it for a walk fairly early into the game.

I used to animate stuff for fun. I can tell you that without idle animations, characters look like mannequins, as if they are unnaturally still / dead. Or like the game is paused.

>that insane soundtrack, one memorable melody after another engraving itself into your mind--not with electro or acid jazz but with rocking guitar tunes
>feels like you're actually playing an 80s anime
>no shit like shooting each other, just an insane maximum-tension Grand Prix where the best drivers in the world try outskilling each other and challenging themselves
>despite 30 cars/drivers on screen, they have a lot of personality and you can actually feel bad when they get blasted to smithereens right in front of you while you're trying not to end up like them
>can go so fast you can get fully separated from the road and either regain control or get planed off into space
>moments like that never feel scripted but like there is an actual aerodynamic drag or airflow to reckon with when you're racing 360° on a tube or slicing through the air like a meteor

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Playing Soul Reaver 1 and 2 back to back is so weird. Soul Reaver 1 was nothing short of impressive on the PSX despite the fairly boring gameplay. The textures, the lighting, the effects, the music, the mechanics, switching between the physical and spectral realm in real time in an open world without a single loading screen in sight was no doubt a work of technical geniuses, and it's no wonder the game is so short - it's all packed in one disc.
But then you play Soul Reaver 2 on PS2 and... well, it's the exact same gameplay with better graphics. The animation is impressive sure, but other than that it's barebones. It should've done so much more for being a PS2 game, double the amout of technical prowess Soul Reaver 1 had at the very least. Granted they only had about 2 years to make it but still, it should've done what AAA adventure games are doing today.
But all in all, the gameplay in the Kain series is not its strong point, and can be summed up as "you walking to the next cutscene", but the writing carries it really fucking hard and it rewards patience with a really cool story.

i forget what the actual coined "law" for it, but it's basically: the time needed to complete a software project will fill up whatever time that is alloted for it. that is: if you're given a team and a year to finish a game, you'll finish it in that year. if you're given 5 years, it will take you 5 years.

it's mostly a reflection on software management and how it's changed. yeah sure devs have more tools and shit, but that's because their management gave them those tools. stop shitting on the devs and get angry at the people managing them. why is this SS remake taking so long? well, it's because they're not beholden to a release date. it's the same deal with star citizen. just because you're a good developer doesn't mean you're a good project manager.

it all starts with the management, folks

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9542663
This. A single artist can create every graphic asset needed for a Genesis game within a few months without much trouble. The only way a single artist today is making all the graphics themselves is for a simple indie game that doesn't even try to be graphically impressive.
Just look at the shift between AAA game design teams in the 90's and AAA game design teams in the 00's. Warcraft 2(1995) had a team of nearly 70 people, including 5 programmers, 1 guy just to make levels, 6 people doing 3D art, etc. Huge team for a videogame from 1995. 7 short years later in 2002, Warcraft 3 was released. It has 320 people listed in the credits including 18 programmers, 18 artists, and 8 people working on level design. Well over 4 times the size of the WC2 team. How many industries have their development/production costs go up 4X in the space of a decade? It's precisely why AAA game companies stopped being experimental and now just sticks with evergreen IPs and remakes. Putting a team of 20-30 people on a big risk is one thing, putting 200+ people on a big risk is very costly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541217
N64tismo here, it's better than ever now
PJ64 is still the easiest and most toaster-friendly way to emulate the console and there's ways to disable the annoying support-nagging message.
There's a lot of Mupen64plus builds with user-friendly GUIs if you don't want to deal with PJ64, Mupen RMG and Simple64 are the best options imo.
Retroarch has the parallel64 core which tries to be as accurate as possible, you need a good PC to run it so have that in mind, the Mupen64 cores also work fine enough but you need to setup the core settings properly first, I did that and I can play N64 games alright on my phone.
For Graphics plugins, GLideN64 is the best for speed/low-specs and other things like custom texture-loading, Angrylion plus and Parallel are the most accurate ones but you need a good computer/phone to run them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541217
Just use simple64, it's an improved version of mupen64plus with the ParaLLEl stuff. It's better than the Retroarch version by virtue of not being tied to Retroarch. ParaLLEl improved emulation a lot, but you could only get it through Retroarch, which is why those names have been popping up for years.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541217
It's quite decent now, but there's still some caveats. Project64 is a bit of a clown show now. The last stable build is alright, but the latest nightlies are full of regressions, with games that used to just work without fiddling breaking left and right, and I would stay away from them for the moment. It also doesn't come with the best available plugins (particularly the ParaLLEl plugins), so you gotta get those from elsewhere for the best experience.

On the Mupen side of things, it's sort of split between RMG, Mupen64Plus-Next and simple64. The first one is a straightforward fork that just bundles an actually usable GUI and the best plugins, so it's quite good. The second is RetroArch's version, which from my experience has the best audio and input latency and can use nifty shaders, but has a couple of performance regressions here and there. The last one is a hard fork that's more accurate than the others and fixes issues present in every other emulator and only uses a single set of VERY accurate plugins for extra simplicity, but it's also the slowest.

Then there's ares. It's currently the least compatible of all the emulators, but it could potentially become the best one, as it's essentially taking a bsnes approach. Overall, I wouldn't much recommend it over simple64 just yet, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541297
Some of it has to do with the N64's unusual architecture, but a lot of it has to do with its history. It was heavily fractured between a bunch of competing emulators, and a lot of design decisions were made early on across all the emulators (mostly for performance and short-term-gain reasons) that hit a brick wall around 2010 or so and froze progress for a good while. The worst of it was heavy reliance on HLE graphics emulation, which is inherently hacky and heavily contributed to the plugin hell situation the scene is known for, and the other is lack of proper cycle counting, instead relying on hacky workarounds like CounterFactor. Sure, this allowed you to play Mario 64 on a Pentium III, but it caused countless issues for a myriad other games, and the scene was very slow to transition away from the HLE-hacks-and-workarounds approach. Only now are they finally embracing LLE and accurate cycle counting as worthwhile goals to fix the remaining problems.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541346
The N64 is a lot more complex than the hardware before it. I'd wager writing a whole new emulator from scratch isn't easy. Also, not all of its ins-and-outs are documented yet (of course, there's the infamous Oman archive leak that most likely was consulted by early emulator devs, but that's neither here nor there). I think at the end of the day, though, there just wasn't much interest. Most of the popular games are plenty playable even on toasters, and that's what they ultimately cared about. Without a byuu-like autist to push the envelope, complacency tends to kick in.

There was, of course, CEN64, but unfortunately its developer had somewhat unrealistic expectations about being able to get it to run at good speeds on current rigs, and when he was unable to achieve it, he sort of lost interest and left it to the n64dev community, and now it's more of a documenting/debugging tool than anything.

Speaking of byuu, ares is the most current attempt at a highly accurate emulator written from the ground up for accuracy without (mostly) relying on older code, and it's made pretty good progress, all things considered, even if its RDP renderers aren't original. Still has a good way to go, though.

simple64 is the closest thing. It's not perfect, of course, but it does appear to have the overall highest compatibility at the moment. There is one notable regression with it, though, in that it freezes in Jet Force Gemini's intro cutscene. You can get around this by resetting and reloading the save, and you'll be able to progress past it. AFAIK this is the only big notable game with a noticeable issue not present in the other emulators.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541395
The Wii isn't just similar - it's practically an overclocked GameCube. I do believe its GPU has some extra capabilities, but overall support was relatively trivial to add. I will give them that they seized on the whole PR thing MUCH better than anyone in the N64 scene did, though that's not too surprising since most of them are hobbyists or come from the old school way of doing things. Most were slow to get on the whole Kickstarter/Patreon thing.

In any case, Dolphin isn't without its problems. It just papers over them better. Some games are still unplayable on it to this day, such as Rogue Squadron III.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541395
GC and Wii have a more traditional hardware architecture, so emulating them using OpenGL or DirectX are simpler. The N64, however, has an alien an primitive architecture, it was derived from a SGI workstation so it predates OpenGL and common 3d conventions. Emulating that is hell.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541443
>Emulating that is hell
With hardware-rendered HLE, yes. Even GLideN64, the most advanced HLE plugin, still has a bunch of problems, and it's like a game of whack-a-mole where they fix one problem only for another to pop up, and then it turns out it's still fucked on AMD or Intel or whatever anyway. Software-rendered LLE rendering fixes damn near everything, but it was much more demanding, and even with multi-threading it's still a bit too much for some games. Thankfully we got ParaLLEl-RDP, which is damn near magical.

>>9543340
After doing a quick google search, I learned that the KV-27FS100 has component at 480i only which makes it perfect for pairing it with the Analog I/O board and simply using a VGA to component breakout. Cleanest analog picture you can get on a stock consumer tube. Personally, my only concern is that since it's a flat panel (as opposed to curved), it will most likely have noticeable geometry warping which is very common but easy to get used to. I don't have personal experience with this set though and only basing my assumption on previous experience with Sony flat tubes.

>>9543343
Yeah, there is a setting if you look through the core's OSD options. Increasing the clockspeed to turbo helped me out a ton in several games that don't have the SA-1 patch like Battle Pinball. Unfortunately, I don't think it helps much in a game like Starfox which still chugs.

posts.com: Only played the 1st one. Soundtrack, atmosphere, character designs and all that were very memorable. Combat wise, it places a lot more emphasis on guarding/absorbing/repelling than other SMT's I've played. You have a more standard RPG party as opposed to the demon collecting. The hunting and eating system is really interesting at first but I feel like it can become a chore if you're trying to fight the end game bosses and level up all your shit. Even though SMT de-emphasizes grinding I still feel as though you can get forced into situations where you 100% need a certain skill or monster which you can then only get through brute forcing combat encounters until the right demon pops up. In DDS this can happen with the way the mantra grid works. I thought the last leg of the game was a real slog too. Generally the dungeons and bosses aren't as interesting as Maniax Nocturne but it's still worth a play. I read the plot of the 2nd game and it sounded fucking retarded.

>>9541996
>Where is the SCART port lol

Sadly SCART never existed on NTSC-U TV's. At some point in the early 90's TV's started adding S-Video in models that were 25inch or larger. S-Video still doesn't look comparable to SCART. In later 90's NTSC TV's from 1997 and onwards, component was added. But, at that point, we were getting closer to HDTV's being a reality.

An overenthusiastic employee made a bunch of ridiculously difficult mazes for the game. They used them in the game just because they didn't want to hurt his feelings. Recognizing that the mazes are, in fact, ridiculous, they included a full guide with the game.
You can go through and draw maps of all the dungeons. This is how I like to do it. It's a kind of challenge that doesn't exist in RPGs anymore. For patient people, it's fun.
Or you can skip all that trouble and use the maps that were included with the game. It's still fun, although there is a bit of grinding. I kind of like the grinding.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: PS2 is my favourite game of all time but you have to enjoy grinding to enjoy it. I fucking love grinding a JRPG party, and I love the difficulty curve of PS2. You are kept perpetually poor, forcing you to work hard to upgrade your party. The ability to configure your party membership throughout the game creates emergent gameplay, like patrolling a small area of the map with a party of 2 to fast level specific party members with specific powers. The difficulty curve makes the minimal story elements all the more satisfying when they're delivered. And the music, aesthetics and atmosphere are just perfect. Its telling that when Sega rebooted Phantasy Star for the Dreamcast, it was the look and feel of PS2 that they sought to translate into 3d

>>9535101
Not sure about bugs, I'm OP and I'm playing the improvement patch. It fixes most of the retarded stuff, like super slow walk speed, screen flashing red several times on every hit, game text being all caps, and so on. The game's script is also updated, some items are renamed to be more consistent with the later games. The game mechanics are all preserved intact, there are just light overhauls to tech learning order here and there, as well as removal of the most obviously useless weapons/items. I guess it's the best option if you want the most vanilla version of the game without the bugs / text errors / irritating stuff. there's an option to turn on double exp / meseta if you want, you'll need to apply a separate patch that comes in the archive.
My only gripe with the patch is that the walk speed is a tiny bit fast for towns, doing precise movement may be a bit hard, but it's way worth saved time.

>it's a fucking labyrinth
Yeah, they are. The way I understand it, you are supposed to beat them in several tries: go in, explore, teleport away, heal, go back.
Or use the guide. The mazes are not that complicated though, except for >>9529090
A couple of gameplay hints:
Grinding become easier halfway through the game when you get a set of armor in the second dam that casts Gra with no TP charge.
Robots and magical enemies tend to resist melee damage. Guns and techs ignore resistance.
All guides tell that Kain's techs work on robots and Hugh's techs work on biomonsters. What they don't tell you is that they both work on magical enemies in the later dungeons.

>Is the original really so buggy?
here's a small sample:
- dialogue text bugs (some lines are accidentally omitted or attributed to the wrong character)
- Laconian Dagger, a weapon bought/found late game, having an attack stat of 4 instead of 40
- Hugh is unable to cast Gires outside of battle
- missing sounds during spellcasting for certain techniques
- contrary to what >>9535364 's tech list states, Shinb was meant to allow a guaranteed escape from battle with biomonsters when cast, but the tech was broken and never worked
- If you choose to DEFEND in battle and then on the next turn use an item or cast a tech, the DEFEND status is maintained, only choosing ATTACK will cause it to drop
- missing animation frames from some enemies in battle

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9539613
I used to think so too, even after playing through it once getting all four endings by abusing the save system. The battle system needed work (put all points into healing, none of the other techniques matter because melee combat too strunk), the localization drops massive amounts of story detail that was in the Japanese version, monster design and animations leave a lot to be desired after the phenomenal work in the last two games, and a lot of the towns and dungeons feel very copy-and-paste. Why is there a sunny, grass-filled village in the middle of a terminally snowy dome?

Basically, the game feels very unfinished and lacking polish. That being said, the music is on par with some catchy tunes (not many though) and the Generations system gives the game a little bit of added replay value even if by the red generation everything basically wraps up in the exact same way despite the 2nd generation going to great lengths to pit you on either side of the Orakian-Layan war depending on your choice of bride at the end of the 1st.

There's actually a fun little jrpg to have here if you can get passed some of its quirks. It's a lot more forgiving and less-grindy than PS2, at least.

That said, the enemies in JSR can fuck off. That's my only real complaint. They aren't fun to deal with, they are purely nuisances and when you get hit it feels like bullshit most of the time. Especially with those flying fuckers near the end of the game.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You are brought into this world inside a lab, built piece by piece and awakened from the void. Your maker, standing next to you, calls you his greatest creation - his "best attempt", in his own words. Before you are given a reason to be conscious, but you are given a purpose - to protect your creator and all those who are like him. You learn that you are not the first of your kind, let alone the last. There are others like you, but none are as strong as you are. Some, too, are protectors, but you alone are their leader, built to defend this strange thing called "society" that you are now part of.

What this purpose means in practice, though, is that in order to protect, you must destroy. You discover that there are others like you who act erratically, against their own purpose. Something corrupts them, pushes them to disobey, to be irregular, or so you are told. The cause of such illogical behavior soon helps you understand that you are fundamentally different from your creator: Your kind, hailed as his greatest achievement, is in fact flawed at a deeper level. You are susceptible to defects that can wrestle your self control away from you, corrupt your body and mind, and make you a monster.

You then realize the worst of it: Your creator, when ill, is healed. One of your kind, when stricken with something similar, is destroyed. Destroyed by someone like you.

Is that why you exist? To serve, and then be dismantled? Why is disobecience from your kind, willing or not, met with imprisonment or execution? Why must you destroy others like you in your makers' stead? Why can't you even voice your concerns, as if you were programmed not to? You were made a flawed thing - a copy of another, older being with no such flaws, as you've also discovered - were you, then, made by flawed hands?

This is not freedom. You despise human error, and so do others. There must be a solution. And you do have a solution.

Rebellion.

X8's plot twist is that the new generation reploids should be immune to the virus due to their copy chips, but they ended up with Sigma's DNA in the mix and decided to willingly follow his ideals (even going as far as to look down on all older generation reploids). This is why they go some form of "we're totally not mavericks guise we swear.
Maverick Hunter X was seemingly going to stick with the "reploid consciously doing bad" take, but given the virus elements came in around X2 and X3 (along X5's plot and Wily's implied involvement in X2 and others) it's unclear if that would've stayed true or if it was merely a misdirect.

Here is my incredibly autistic headcanon on all of this:
>Bass does his wounded gazelle act in Mega Man 7 to get access to Light Labs and loot the place for Wily. Here, he acquires a copy of the design documents for X.
>Wily reads these design documents and concludes that X is the proverbial nuke in the arms race between him and Light. He works on building Zero to counter X.
>Because Wily thinks X is a weapon like every other Robot Master, he never considers that X's code might result in a non-aggressive or fully autonomous robot. This also explains why Zero has X's armour upgrades built into his design. Wily doesn't understand why Light would intentionally weaken his own weapon by locking X's full strength behind separate components.
>Wily finishes Zero and is shocked when Zero states he doesn't want to fight Light and doesn't see why he should have to listen to Wily. Wily deactivates Zero to fix his "programming error".
>Wily is able to get Zero interested in fighting generally, but he can't get through Zero's autonomy.
>Wily decides to get around his inability to reprogram Zero by building an algorithm that will patch Zero to be loyal to him by rewriting his code.
>Wily also realizes that a program that switches a robot's allegiance is pretty useful generally. So, he instructs the algorithm to make its final "loyalty patch" a virus that infects nearby machines.
>This is also why Wily works on reprogramming Light's machines and the Roboenza virus in Mega Man 9 and 10 respectively. He's effectively doing R&D for what he believes to be the final step in his nuke.
>For one final failsafe, Wily also instructs the algorithm to jump to any machines it believes "defeated" Zero. That way, if Mega Man or X beats Zero, Wily still wins by getting control of them.

>>9543404
X went through 100+ of simulations in a pod in order to learn proper morality, good and evil, and the weight of his choices. This is his Suffering Circuit, which is the core aspect of his mind that allows him to have true free will. Cain's Reploids do not have that as he did not put them through similar tests, and have no qualms about killing humans or other Reploids when they go Maverick. They have the innocence of kids (innocence being defined as the lack of guilt), but with the physical power of a machine to match. No different than a 5 year old killing a bird with their toy slingshot out of curiosity.
Vile is one of the big examples of this: He was a Maverick Hunter who was far too violent at his job, destroying whatever he had to destroy to get shit done. He didn't care if an entire neighborhood was reduced to rubble as long as he killed (not aprehended, KILLED) the mavericks he's tasked to take care of.
X on the other hand is so considerate that he'll even hesitate to shoot through a Reploid to hit a maverick with his buster cannon, as shown in the Day of Sigma. He's fully capable of doing that but he doesn't allow himself to do that. Every Reploid that sees him do stuff like this is left dumbfounded because they simply can't fathom the concept of guilt on the same level. This is a deep flaw Dr. Light made sure to iron out when building X, so much in fact that he died waiting for this flaw to be fixed.
So yes, in short, Cain made Reploids flawed from the start.

>don't forget the whole "saturn was popular in japan" meme, when the system stopped getting any real games in japan after 1998
That's because they dropped support for it immediately after the Dreamcast came out, much to the annoyance of a lot of developers and consumers. It's part of why the Dreamcast didn't really take off in Japan and why it didn't really get the same level of third party support that the Saturn got in Japan.

The truth of the matter is that the Saturn actually was doing well in Japan. The system had outsold the N64 in both hardware and software. While the N64 had more first party titles breaking 1 million, it's sales fell off a cliff once you got outside of that. While on the Saturn third party titles were actually selling fairly well in Japan. It was enough that it was turning heads of companies like Konami to start testing the waters with ports of big name PS1 games like Suikoden, Vandal Hearts, and Symphony of the Night, with Metal Gear Solid apparently being looked into. But then Sega abruptly pulled the plug on it once the Dreamcast came out.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9542957
>They were losing billions of yen on making the console
No they weren't. The losses on hardware pretty much stopped by around 1996 when the Model 2 system came out. At launch they were losing about $100 per system, which is the same loss Sony was taking on the PS1. But as RAM prices fell and the hardware was more consolidated it got a lot cheaper to produce. The massive loss people post graphs showing is from the fact that Sega of Japan wrote off a bunch of unsold Genesis inventory that was sitting at Sega of America which lowered the perceived value of the US Branch as that inventory was being marked on financials as assets.
>the only title that sold good was Virtua Fighter and maybe Sakura Taisen.
You think that having 5 games selling over 1 Million means N64 sold more software? You're not looking at the big picture. When you look at the actual sales data you see that Saturn had a lot more games selling well and charting in the weekly sales charts. This site documents all the Famitsu sales charts of the era. And it shows that Saturn had a lot more games charting over it's run than the N64 did.
https://sites.google.com/site/gamedatalibrary/game-search

And from official shipped numbers from Nintendo, and Sega's FY98 report we know that N64 sold about 39 Million games in Japan, and Saturn sold close to around 54 Million games in Japan. It outsold the N64 in both hardware and software.

>Saturn had too poor of a software attach rate to do well.
From Sega's FY98 report they had sold 8.8 Million Saturn's worldwide, and 80 Million Saturn games worldwide. That would put the worldwide attach rate at ~9:1. The Japanese attach rate was probably higher than that as that average is being pulled down by the systems poor western performance. N64's attach rate by comparison was about 6-7:1.

>It outsold the N64 for one quarter in a 4 year period
It outsold the N64 while it was actively being supported.

Are you? Do you not understand the key factor here? Sega of America was producing Genesis games and Systems like it was still 1992 well into 1996. And on top of it they were including that unsold inventory that was piling up in warehouses as assets in their financials. When Shoichiro Irimajiri took over as CEO of Sega of America after Kalinske he quickly realized how mismananged the US branch was and how much the financials were being misrepresented. One of the first things he did was fix all that. That resulted in things that were being included as assets in Sega of America's financials to suddenly no longer be there as they were written off as what they actually were, losses. This is what caused the large loss that was reported in the FY98 report. It's all there in the first 2 pages:
https://segaretro.org/images/f/fe/AnnualReport1998_English.pdf

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9542256
Basically every classic shmup in existence has large hitboxes. Large hitboxes tie intrinsically into the gameplay. Small hitboxes (which came quite a bit later) were the downfall of the genre because it meant stages changed from interesting level design, macro dodging, hazard dodging, interesting setpieces, learning routes and tactics, etc to now just static backgrounds, enemies with no thematic cohesion or relevance, and having these complex slow-moving curtains of bullets with tiny little hitboxes that you slowly weave through with your tiny little hitbox.

The hitboxes in Silver Surfer are great because it's literally exactly as it shows: your whole character, and you can easily tell where the stage hazards are by what you can't shoot through. The slow scroll and tight controls allow you to weave through the levels with ease.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9541762
Shaders are only half of the equation. The best ones already emulate scanlines and phosphor masks very well when used at very high resolutions. However, the display matters a lot as well, and it's where the bottleneck truly lies. You need at least 4K resolution, HDR with very high brightness and strobing to properly replicate things like scanline bloom and smooth motion while having a nice vibrant picture. In lieu of that, some shaders try to fake the bloom and glow of a CRT screen, but these aren't all that convincing.

SHVC units are the SNES equivalent of the first Famicoms from '83 that got recalled. Avoid that shit garbage; the chips in those self-destruct. The single PPU models (RGB, 1-Chip, and SNES Jr) have some technical changes as well as a different and sharper video signal with the GPM-02 being the only stable, reliable version of the original twin chip PPU.

Yes unfortunately with the early SNESes they rushed out an incomplete beta model and relied on customers to do their field testing for them.

It's some primitive form of Dolby Surround that uses math to encode additional audio channels in the two sterel outputs. I had seen a translated Japanese site where a guy mentions having a really early Famicom from the initial production run and that not only did the PPU get quite hot but it had a really dirty video signal with a lot of interference (this was later fixed by putting a metal shield around the cartridge slot). Apparently (and this was as far as I could discern from Google Translate) it didn't have the full 8 sprites per line either on this initial revision PPU and there was a lot of sprite dropout.

They also had membrane A and B buttons on the early Famicoms that would fall off and were hard to press so those got replaced by hard plastic ones on Rev D onward.

>>9540847
PC compatibles had no sinks up to 386s with the 486 being the first generation to need one and this eventually grew from just a sink to an entire huge fan stack and modern PC cases have vent holes in them as well. There was a thread on VCFED about the necessity of heat sinks in early PCs and it was said that the 8086/88 had no need of them, probably not a 286 either--also there existed CMOS versions of those chips which don't get above room temperature. x87 chips did get hot and needed sinks; they used cerdip packages for thermal reasons.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
https://web.archive.org/web/20161106221828/http://jpx72.detailne.sk/collection_files/consoles_files/con_gallery_famicom5.htm

This link shows a Rev A Famicom with the heat sink underneath the PPU. Guy acquired this one, couldn't get it to work, and sold it to a dude in Slovakia, whose archived site is shown here. It displayed a green screen which means the PPU was working but an apparently unresponsive CPU.

It should be stressed that these initial Famicom PCBs from 1983 are rare as they were recalled and the vast majority of them swapped for Rev B boards. If you find a square button Famicom it's usually always a Rev B board.

No. What much, much more likely happened was that most Blaster Master games after the first were developed by a UK studio. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you're trying to learn Japanese by playing retro games, in my opinion there's nothing better than the EMIT trilogy by Koei.
Visual novels are ideal for learning Japanese in general, but EMIT was specifically made as language teaching software so it goes above and beyond. The whole VN is written in both English and Japanese and you can flip back and forth at any time, and it even includes an in-game dictionary.
The story is fun and the whole trilogy is only about 90 minutes long in total. You can read it on about any platform you can imagine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9542513
Here's a literal rendering. It's really line 3 that gets gutted in the process, even if it's pretty well implied
>I've been calling from the train station.
>It started to rain, and I wanted (to tell) someone to bring me an umbrella.
>But the line's been tied up, and I couldn't get through at all.
However, taking the last line at its literal value sort of misses that he's admonishing his daughter who is holding the phone right there as he's walking in. As if to say
>But SOMEONE's been tying up the line, and I couldn't get through
So while it doesn't cling to the source text word-for-word, it does properly convey the intent. Too bad that's not really good for teaching people a language, who might be scratching their heads about why the conversation plays out so differently.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541383
It was supposed to be the first entry in a franchise of bilingual visual novels called "English Dream" but I don't think it did very well, so it was cut short pretty soon after.
The only other entry was called Dark Hunter (also by Koei, natch). I haven't tried it personally, but it seems like a good place to start.
I also know of one other non-retro VN with the same system called Go! Go! Nippon! ~My First Trip to Japan~. I haven't tried it either. It looks atrocious but I imagine it would still be valuable as a learning aide.

Past that the best thing I can think of is Gyakuten Saiban Yomigaeru Gyakuten, the Japanese version of Phoenix Wright Ace Attorney. That version contains both the Japanese and English scripts. The Japanese was taken out of the English localization because lol fuck Americans right?
You can only flip languages on the title screen so it might be more inconvenient but it's something. Probably the most fun way to learn Japanese legal lingo like 弁護士 and 尋問.
Gyakuten Saiban 2 and 3 on the DS are also bilingual.
IMO Yomigaeru is okay, 2 is okay, and 3 is really really fucking good, but you have to read Yomigaeru and 2 first to appreciate it. The trilogy is well worth experiencing.

If you'd still like more options after that I'd recommend getting the following:
Interactive Text Hooker
Translation Aggregator
A list of "H-Codes" (here's mine, it's out of date but it works: https://mega.nz/file/GJ80yKKD#vE3_reEKpmETjiaLepo5SczaL5UIbtyv45BOQkSJxUU)
Put those together and you can machine translate most visual novels. If you highlight one word at a time you have an instantaneous electronic dictionary.

Good luck!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9542943
That and ウィッシュルーム/ラストウィンドウ on DS are pretty decent since both of those, and of course 逆転裁判, regularly check your understanding of the situation in various ways, rather than simply allowing you to whitenoise the text passively.
Also, at least in the original trilogy, gyakusai's text boxes can only be so long. You usually don't get blasted with mile-long sentences with multiple clauses, so it's not a bad place for beginners to cut their teeth on "real" reading without the meme tier vocab/grammar of "real" VNs slowing them down.
The court/police/detective/forensic vocab only makes up a few hundred of the words you'd need to learn at best, so overcoming that small hurdle is nothing in the scheme of things.

posts.com:
>>9539823
I have a hunch as to what the problem was. My suspect is that ARAH was one of those games that reads back the PPU registers but that only works on Rev G chipsets (on earlier revisions they're read only). The Rev G was introduced during 1989 so a NES made before that date will have the older Rev E chips. Best way to test for this without opening it up is running Micro Machines as that will glitch on the title screen if you have a Rev E.

MM was an unlicensed game to fair, but ARAH and TTA were licensed yet it's possible that they eluded Nintendo's Q/C checks anyway. A playtester at Nintendo probably just ran the games on a Rev G console and they worked with no problems so it passed. The fact that both games are quite late ones would also mean there was a good chance that the devs were using Rev G NESes to play and test them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Famicoms with the hockey stick logo on the front had the revision G chipset so they're easy to identify. for NESes it's a little harder but IIRC the chipset change coincided with Nintendo switching to fireproofed ABS plastic so if the NES looks yellowed it's probably a Rev G chipset, but only running Micro Machines would confirm it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In their context, when originally released, SMB3 was a better game. It was late in the NES life and was the crowning achievement of the console. It had horizontal and vertical scrolling (don't take that for granted), a huge number of levels and tilesets, a bunch of powers and upgrades, a diverse world, etc. In comparison, the base game of SMW is inferior.

However, currently, SMW is a better game due to rom hacks and kaizos. SMW does have far better movement than SMB3 and is a much better foundational "base" for hacks and mods.

SMB3 should've had tighter movement and fewer autoscrollers (way too damn many). SMW should've had better levels, but that's fixed with modern kaizos.

not that anon but it's pretty obvious. 3 has tons of levels but they're all 5 seconds long, so that the map feature will work as intended. NES games were famously strapped for content due to all the restrictions of the era, having a game where you could willingly skip tons of the levels in various ways meant that each one needed to be bite-sized so it wouldn't impact things too much on either end. but that wound up creating a negative experience in the end since by the time you get into the groove of playing the level will already be over, just as that anon said.

world was properly able to flesh out the idea of a map and tons of optional levels due to the console it was on, but unfortunately was rushed as mentioned above. both have many compromises for their respective systems.

They're both great games, SMB3 in spite of the hardware and SMW in part because of it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
We all have that one special video game in our memory, you know the one, that one which pretty much everyone seems to dislike, with the general consensus being that it is subpar and not even close to being good, and yet... you like it, regardless if it's because you grew up with it and have fond memories of it, or if you picked it up in recent years and actually liked it for real. I have several of these to be honest, though that's probably because I grew up with some shovelware, and because I always try to beat a video game once I pick it up, regardless if I find it good or not, and anything can become enjoyable once you're used to it and get good at it.

I thought it'd be fun to make a thread dedicated to all of these video games that aren't gems, but are instead regular or even ugly rocks... but they're our rocks, and we see the beauty in them even if it isn't obvious to everyone else, it'll be fun to list them and even talk a little about them in depth if you prefer. Out of the top of my head I can think of several subpar adventures that I quite enjoyed, like Ariel: The Little Mermaid (MD), Donald Duck: Goin' Quackers (PS), Sonic 3D Blast (MD), The Lion King: Simba's Mighty Adventure (PS), Yu-Gi-Oh! Duel Monsters (GB)... I could go on and on for quite some time, I've spent so many hours playing all of these.

However, the one that probably sticks out to me the most is Spider-Man: Return of the Sinister Six. I had it on my PolyStation, a Famiclone, and always got stuck on the 2nd and 3rd stages, but kept replaying and loving it... it took me by surprise that it was seen as awful by most, I recall watching the AVGN Spider-Man episode and being somewhat puzzled, though I still found that bit funny. I always hear about how it controls badly, but honestly, while the controls aren't the best, you get used to them in a couple of minutes, they're not hard to figure out, and once you do, you can start to appreciate the level design, especially in the 2nd and 3rd levels.

>>9543750
I'll admit that Electro can be frustrating because he moves around so much, and goes below the floor often, where you can't hit him at all... I've struggled with him a lot before, especially when I played it in my childhood, but nowadays I have a couple of strategies to beat him quickly and easily, for the most part, depending if you have webbing or not.

If you don't have webbing, wait for him to get near you and punch him, but don't tap the button, hold it, Spider-Man will do a longer punch that does more damage.

If you do have webbing, just keep shooting at him while standing, if he's in the same altitude as you, or jumping, if he's above you, to end the fight quickly.

I recall a couple of parts on the 2nd stage where you could get sort of stuck, but it's never truly impossible to progress.
In the first instance, the pit without the exploding platform, you have to websling using the crate in the middle, you go back and forth until you manage to jump to the right, after that you need to jump to the left from the very edge of the platform as Spider-Man almost slides through the ceiling, and then you escape.
In the other spot where you can get sort of locked, with the exploding platform, it's even simpler, all you have to do is stand on the crate next to the one that exploded, and websling to the other side.
I have to admit that it ain't easy, but none of these parts are impossible to progress through, they're just really precise and way too punishing...

>>9533447
That article is blatantly wrong. The program was not made as a diss, and it was definitely not shown to any lawyers as an act of pettiness, it was just a silly private joke shown to a couple friends.

Here's David Crane's personal explanation of it:
>“The Venetian Blind cart is a working 2600 demo that shows a landscape at sunset outside a window, covered by a fully operational Venetian Blind — one that moves up and down under joystick control. Here is how it came about:
>When Atari sued Activision they laid claim to certain ‘proprietary’ techniques. One technique for which they claimed ownership was first used by Bob Whitehead in the display code of the Atari Chess cartridge. This method moved the display objects back and forth every scan line to allow the game to display more objects. On the chess pieces, for example, Bob showed the odd pixel row of the odd numbered columns of pieces and the even pixel row of the even numbered columns. We called this the Venetian Blind technique since it made the pieces look like they were being viewed through a venetian blind.
>One day in the lab at Activision while the lawsuit was in full swing, Bob and I collaborated on a practical joke. We made a display showing an architecturally accurate window with a view of a grassy hill at sunset. We covered it with a venetian blind effect that animated up and down (complete with the stacking up of the slats as they were gathered up by the blind mechanism). We took it to CES and showed it to a few people who were privy to the lawsuit, asking ‘Is this what Atari means by the Venetian Blind Technique?’
>The joke was on us in one respect, when we realized that we had made public our latest innovation (the background sunset) when we showed it to our competitors. (Several games in the lab were using this new idea, but they had not yet been published.) As it turned out, nobody picked up on our slip and nobody beat us to market with the sunset.” ~ David Crane

I can think of two ancient video games that made me feel this way as a kid. First I literally have never thought about until now. Some dirty cheap floppy disk 8-bit dos looking poor man’s monkey island point and click adventure game. It was about a man going on holiday and he had to fly on cheap plane loaded with chickens. I remember feeling dread and disgust as a kid for no reason just because of how cheap it felt. I guess it was probably some obscure home brew game from the time.
The second was an Australian history edutainment game about the first fleet but you played as a convict. In the shop hold you could interact with things. There was a sick guy and when you examine him he had plague. If you stole his bible your character died of plague. In the hold there was this creepy early cgi eerie shadowed criminal who gaslighted and baited you into siding with him. If you let him corrupt you you kind of escape the guards but they eventually shoot you and kill you both. It dealt with my too much blood and death for something out of a scholastic magazine my teacher was trialing after hours at my small Christian school. Disgusting and dread inducing .

I played a part of KH1 as a kid and played through the whole game a couple weeks ago. I had a good enough time, though I found it pretty easy once you got Second Chance. Then I played KH2 which I had never played. I dropped 2. I think a little bit of the jank worked for the first game, prevented you from being too much of a god and gave you reason to use your other abilities. I've seen people insist 2 isn't just mash X to win and your magic is good, but it felt like they streamlined melee attacks but not magic so you either mash X and do a ton of damage or you entirely break your flow to cast a couple spells that do next to nothing. It didn't help that it felt like 2 was dripfeeding you spells, too. I ended up dropping 2 because the combat just wasn't very interesting to me and the amount of cutscenes was just frustrating with how often it took control away from you. And that Roxas intro was so dull.

Overall, I think KH1 was the better game, even though it had its annoyances; I found that I probably didn't finish the game as a retarded child because I kept thinking "where the fuck do I go" and it'd be things like climbable vines that didn't stand out well enough against a tree and things like that.

Yeah, when they’re done well.

Inserting cartoon characters into an already well-established and popular aesthetic (in this case basketball/hip hop) works because it doesn’t break the layer of irony that comes with it. In the case of those Looney Tunes, it’s “cool” because it’s kind of funny.

Whereas with this shit >>9525010, it’s Mickey Mouse trying WAY too hard to look cute in an edgy, almost emo sort of way. The aesthetic itself is NOT well-established so we as the viewer have no idea what he’s trying to pull off with that pose and that outfit. It actually, literally begs the question
>what the fuck did he mean by this?

We can’t feasibly see this as funny, because it’s evident that Mickey is 100% serious about looking like he belongs in a fucking boyband. There is no layer of irony to it, and that is what makes it awkward and uncool.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
KH1 has got the most perfect pacing when it comes to gameplay progression and powercreep

Sora starts with very simple movement and his attacks are very simple, by the end once you face off the extra bosses you really feel like you have grown as a character specially if you craft all end game weapons for all 3, many games fail at recreating this feel and it's very rewarding

Also I do agree with posts above, end game Sora in KH1 feels very balanced compared to end game Sora in KH2

Having said that though I think I like KH2 for completely different reasons, it being a pseudo Devil May Cry with JRPG elements being one of them, also KH2 is more "anime" than KH1 because of all the 1v1 fights and all the cool shit Nomura included in many of the bosses and general gameplay

Really wished the gameplay would have remained good because Square had something great going on before they killed the franchise with BBS (I also like this entry though but modern KH is nothing like what KH1 and KH2 used to be)

>>9524382
I was 10 when this came out. This shit was mindblowing to a kid. I grew up with Disney cartoons and FF7 was one of the first games I had on PS1. The commercial with simple and clean would play all the time. Yeah this shit was dope, what a time to be alive.
Thankfully I wasn’t super autistic, but the wave of autism this caused at some kids in school was immense (I am thinking about one annoying retard in particular).
Sequel was good too but wasn’t nearly as magical, mostly liked it for Tron world.

My favorite thing about this game was how it starts you off on this ethereal comfy island with all your friends (who are kid versions of characters from final fantasy games you already played) and then it transports you to fucking Disney animated universe with movies you already watched. It was so weird and interesting, and I really like how they did the 2D Disney cartoons in 3D without losing much in translation.
Embarrassing to admit to liking something so autistic but holy shit this was a drug to a child in 2002.
It lives and dies by its incredible opening, that tropical island as your door to a new universe was expertly done.

>>9527356
>don't think I've ever seen a source for that but I've read it in other places. I don't know where the rumor comes from or if it's true.
Right, but it's definitely an idea that's been going around online, true or not. It's a small form of vindication for me at any rate, even finding out that it's definitely untrue would be interesting enough for me.

With some extensive Googling and searching, I found a couple of references to it on TVTropes (unsourced, and who knows when they were added), a brief thread about it on R*ddit from earlier this year, and then some scant few mentions of it in the archives of /vr/ and /v/ dating back the past decade or so.
If it's actually true, potentially the one source is actually in Japanese and it's something that's only been wandering around the western world by word of mouth, and either it was never translated, or the translation of it fell off the web at some point.

What we have to back it is 1, that the claim of the idea has been passed around for a long time (never challenged and never sourced), but of slightly stronger substance, 2, there's some interviews with the devs where they do actually mention that Namco made them change a number of things about the game to tone it down, such as making the zombies less realistic and human looking, making the blood green, etc.
There's no mention about the concept of the player character, but that wouldn't have to mean that it wasn't something which changed during development, regardless of it was something changed in the last minute as often told of, or if it was something which was proposed but nixed early on. The player initially being proposed as an evil killer looking to murder a poor girl, then being changed into a hero trying to save his girl would be going from a darker to a lighter tone, and it would make the fact that the player looks like a famous slasher horror killer less inexplicable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9536428
It isn't complex, no, but there's an appeal in that in itself, Doom is better than Wolfenstein 3D, because the latter is very plain in comparison, but there's a certain fun purity in it too which works (and there's actually a little bit more depth to Wolf3D than people give it credit for). Compare also to how Super Mario Bros. 3 is categorically better than the first Super Mario Bros. and has way more depth, with far more content of greater variety, but it's still fun to play the first one anyway.

If you look at Splatterhouse and think that it should have more complexity to it, then what you'd be looking at is Splatterhouse 3, which has a little bit more gameplay depth, and which also actually has multiple endings. The western release has those endings hanging on really a very strict time limit, so it's actually pretty hard to get the best ending, but the Japanese one is essentially the same (down to being in English), but with a far less harsh timer. Opinions are divisive in the fandom about a lot of things, but there's many who think the third Splatterhouse is the best one, while some dislike how it deviates from the simpler style of the previous games.

There's also the infamous reboot, which isn't really retro (I guess it's sort of a remake, but not really?). Tastes are divided on that one as well, but there's a lot of people who think that while it's indeed rather flawed, the game is actually pretty decent for what it is, and works well enough with the property.

There's also one other significant change in the English version, which I think is much more damning: the invincible spin kick move is a typical belt-scroller style "exchange hp for an invincible reversal" style move in the Japanese version...but in English they gave it a trickier input but in exchange made it totally invincible and costs no HP. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9536624
I love the atmosphere throughout, but Splatterhouse was always quite in your face with the gore, that was the point. I think that the gore is actually rather impressive for the hardware they were working with, mainly to get viscera that good and detailed on a TurboGfx-16 and Sega Genesis, with equally disgusting monster design.
From the arcade game in 1988, to Splatterhouse 3 in August 1993, I can't think of any remotely popular videogame available in the west which has this quality of gore and in these quantities. The only rival is Doom, which is fantastic (especially in that regard), but wouldn't be on the market until December of 1993, and was working with far more permissive memory and color palettes.

Actually, I suppose those Elvira games were quite gory, and about the horror, though they were some sort of adventure games, as opposed to Splatterhouse and Doom being realtime action games, so I guess I could attach that qualifier.

>>9536654
I think that there was no change in the content itself between the Japanese version and the two international versions. They differ slightly, but I think it's little code tweaks/fixes.
There was changes during development of all sorts of kinds (the devs mentioned that the blood used to be red before Namco had them changed to green, for instance), but that was before it made it onto the Japanese market itself. There's some leftover stuff in the release versions, but I'm not sure if it was left out for censorship reasons, as much as things which they cut because they thought didn't fit or was good enough, or because of hardware limitations or not having the time to refine it to the point that they liked.
https://tcrf.net/Splatterhouse_(Arcade)

On the former point, while memorization and trial and error are blatant in a lot of games of the time (though not as much as some people think IMO), some of the stuff in the game just feels annoying to lose a credit too (poltergeist room in particular comes to mind, Biggyman too if you don't know how to beat him with slides or the double shotgun cheese).

When I say expansive...what I mean is like, comparing the gameplay to say Castlevania 1 (odd comparison I know, but it's one of the only classics I can think of which has a similar level of commitment in its movement and attacks) and I feel like there's just a lot more going on in that game in terms of enemy patterns, platforming, secondary systems like sub weapons, etc. at least IMO

Not trying to shit on the game mind you. It's far from a kusoge or anything, it's very functional, plays smooth, and has some great segments and stages. But it's gameplay is a bit stiff and limited IMO. Maybe I'll revisit it today.

It's not a difficult skill to teach yourself in adulthood. The tools and materials don't have to be expensive either.
Just don't be like countertop faggot and buy a desoldering gun before a fucking multimeter. What a dumb cunt.
- Soldering iron
- Solder
- Flux
- Some kind of fan for blowing or sucking up fumes
- Some low-gauge wire for bodging
- Multimeter
- Side cutters
That's basically all you need for basic troubleshooting and repair. If you get really into it you can go for an oscilloscope, a desoldering tool, and whatever other expensive items.

>>9519535
I did get a desoldering pump, it was included with the soldering station as well as the solder itself. It's a 60/40 solder which I understand is the most common one. At this point, I would worry to much about the type of solder, the one you buy at the hardware store is going to be just fine, but if you must know, there is a type of solder material that includes flux inside the solder tube. From what I understand, you really want to get some flux so that you can break the oxidation surface in most metallic components and the solder sticks to it properly. I think that is more important.
And as far as removing solder goes, I'm going to use a desoldering pump, but you may also you those desoldering copper braids.

>>9523926
Took forever. Lots of fucking around with one of those dogshit solder suckers and wick. But there were still a few pins that connect to a large ground plain that I just couldnt get free.

I ended up getting it out with a fucking heat gun. I put the board chip-side down against an iron 45lb plate with the PPU over the center hole. I covered the motherboard with several layers of aluminum foil so that only the PPU pins were exposed. Then I heater it up a bit at a time and started tuggging on the PPU from the bottom underneath the iron plate until eventually I tugged it free

I was so scared that I probably just fried the chip... but it worked. Still going strong to this day

Where the battery connects? Yes, between those two, as well as from one pad of the battery to just about anywhere else. I wiped down the board with alcohol last night, as well as the connectors on the N64 itself, and just tested it again. No difference, game works as usual, but no data stays saved. I don't know if power is completely cut to the cartridge memory when the "Reset" button on the console is used, but using that instead of On/Off still led to memory being erased.
From further reading, the only two things I've discovered are:
1) multiple people in similar situations who said they had broken pin/trace connections to the chips, so they soldered wires directly from whichever pin(s) were disconnected to the appropriate chip. I'd have to spend a lot of time continuity testing and then finding a wire to put on there, which is more work than I'm willing to do, or;
2) I also saw a post from a guy saying that he owns two N64s, and one of them wipes the game data from cartridges he uses with it. If my problem is with the N64, that's possibly another can of worms, and would very likely be the same approach/solution as above. The only other game I have to test with is Mario Kart 64, which holds its data no problem. I don't think it utilizes the same CR2032 battery-based save system / PCB model, so I'm not sure if an N64-based fault would necessarily lead to data wiping on it anyway.

>>9519589
>How do you solder these little fuckers?
one leg at a time. the other responses are fucking with you.
put solder+iron on a pad, slide the component into place (this is called 'tacking it down'), remove iron, solder the other side, and then clean up the first side if nits messy.
>Also how do you extract components without fucking up the solder pads
Use heat, not force. If you use force, shit breaks. Stuff will move with basically zero pressure when it's done right.
The exact method depends on the component (SMD vs TFT, simple two-leg devices vs complex multi-leg devices, etc) but for through-hole stuff you just remove all the solder using a good sucker or braid, gently moving the legs as you do so, and components will fall right out.
for small two-contact SMD stuff, you can usually just use lots of solder and a big tip to heat both sides at the same time and slide them off. components may get damaged due to heat when you do this, but the pads will be fine.
>(and if you do how easy is it to repair)?
Not easy. It's not an "experts-only" skill but it's tedious and not for beginners. practice on shit you dont care about because you WILL cause more damage than you fix the first few times you do it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>9541192
If that's the issue then a soldering iron isn't going to help you anyway. Start off by gently cleaning the laser as well as the censors in the open central area of the laser assembly below where the disc sits. If that doesn't help then there's potentioeters to adjust voltage to the laser assembly for reading CDs and DVDs (your problem would be with reading CDs). And if absolutely nothing like this works, then you'd just replace the entire internal disc drive, which is something that you can just unplug and drop a new one in. No soldering required.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>9541215
Honestly I recommend opening up ALL used consoles that you acquire, even if there's nothing visibly wrong with them. Still good to check under the hood and make sure there's no obvious issues with the components or that the inside is caked with dust and roaches or something. For disassembling a fat PS2 just check out an ifixit guide online. Getting to the disc drive and opening that up isn't hard at all. But it's definitely a lot harder to test because you have to reassemble the drive every time you want to see if doing something solved the issue. But drop-in replacement drives should still be fairly easy to obtain. I think they use a fairly generic drive you can swap out.
